name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Silvia Costa, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the implementation of the Creative Europe programme (2021 to 2027) (COM(2018)0366 - C8-0237/2018 - 2018/0190 (COD) (A8-0156/2019)).

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs from the committee very much for their valuable cooperation and for enriching my report and voting for it by a very large majority in the CULT Committee. The new 'Creative Europe' programme is part of a completely changed context compared to seven years ago, both for the digital revolution and for the need to respond to a major crisis of identity and belonging to Europe and its project. I consider it a great achievement of this parliamentary term to be our strong initiative to finally achieve a European framework of cultural policies, starting with the Year of Cultural Heritage, the strengthening of cultural and creative enterprises, the strategy of international cultural relations and intercultural dialogue, which are now fully included in the new culture agenda. A framework that also sees the creative and audiovisual sector finally inserted into a digital economy, into a digital ecosystem, in which the audiovisual media services directive and the one approved on Tuesday on copyright will determine new rules and also greater financial resources for the sector. As rapporteur, I am satisfied with the new elements in the text, starting with the doubling of the budget from 1.4 to 2.8 proposed to Parliament, and I hope that our indication will be defended by the future Parliament and accepted by the Council of Ministers and that there will therefore be no turning back. We have enriched the three sections of the programme – culture, media and cross-sectoral – with important innovations, starting with a new general objective, alongside that of cooperation and competitiveness, that is, the recognition of the intrinsic value of culture and the central role of artists and cultural professionals. We have reintroduced the article on European added value, also encouraging a narrative of common European roots, unity and diversity, and we have provided for structured action, including with European centres of excellence, to finally define qualitative and quantitative indicators of the impact of cultural policies. I am also delighted that my proposal, made as a former rapporteur for the previous 'Creative Europe' programme, to include a new European and international mobility programme for artists and cultural workers has been taken on board. The sector dedicated to culture is now finally strengthened and divided into four specific areas, which will become dedicated financial lines: music, cultural heritage, architecture, publishing and design. The media sector will support transnational actions to strengthen the skills of curricula in the audiovisual and digital fields, independent production, European co-productions, European cinema and video on-demand (VOD) networks, sales abroad, promotion of new production models and public involvement. We pay special attention to fiction, documentaries, children's films and animation, as well as interactive works including quality narrative video games and multimedia content. It is interesting to note that the programme will support the enhancement of artistic but also artisanal talents and, above all, for the first time a specific reference to the promotion of the recognition of the role of women in the cultural and artistic field is included. There are still too few on the boards of cultural institutions. We have introduced a new line on media literacy, an important action against fake news in support of the quality of journalism and, in addition to the co-financing grants for projects, we have developed important synergies, both with the new InvestEU programme, while maintaining the specificity and conditions of the current existing guarantee instrument for the sector, and with the regional development funds and the new external action financial instrument. Above all, however, we want the programme to be more accessible and to involve young people more. Let me give just two final examples: the new line of support - which I wanted to include and, which all my fellow Members have supported, and I am very happy about - to university radio and media networks that tell Europe to young people, in memory of Antonio Megalizzi and Bartek Orent-Niedzielski, the two young Europhonica journalists barbarically killed in the Strasbourg attack last December. And the second example: we have provided for an object of direct support, alongside the important European Film Academy in Berlin, the European Union Youth Orchestra, founded forty years ago by maestro Claudio Abbado and Lionel Bryer. We continue to support the Europe of culture.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, good morning. It’s a pleasure for me to be here to replace Commissioner Navracsics for this important plenary debate. Promoting cultural and linguistic diversity in Europe and boosting our cultural and creative sectors to ensure they remain world class are essential elements of the European project. Creative Europe has played a major role in this, which is why we want to build on and strengthen this programme after 2020. We want more Europeans to be able to enjoy the wealth of our diverse cultures, benefiting from their undisputed power to embody our common values and promote our shared European identity. I know that the rapporteur, Ms Costa, and her shadow rapporteurs fully support these goals. My sincere thanks go to you, Ms Costa, for the high—quality work you have done on this proposal and the excellent working relations we have enjoyed with you. To live up to our ambition, the Commission’s intention is to continue linking up professionals from different European countries through cooperation projects, partnerships and networks; to keep on connecting Europe’s beautiful audiovisual works with large international audiences; and to continue investing in cross—sectoral innovation. We will do all this because we believe it is the best way to enlarge the horizons of both creators and audiences, while at the same time developing good solutions to cultural issues of common concern across borders. But we also want to support our cultural and creative sectors in adapting to new challenges and making the most of opportunities that are opening up in times of rapid change. This is why we have proposed some new features: a new international window; individual mobility for artists and cultural operators; support for specific cultural sectors, such as music books and publishing; architectural and cultural heritage; a stronger focus on Europe’s audiovisual talents, especially women; encouraging creative spaces for script writing; initiatives to enhance promotion and marketing for European books in Europe and beyond; new innovative cross—sectoral actions, encompassing new technologies such as virtual reality and artificial intelligence for content creation, distribution and promotion; and also a scheme to promote a diverse and pluralistic media environment in Europe, including through media literacy. Dear Members of Parliament, I am pleased that you welcome these novelties and, more generally, that you agree on the ambition, the architecture and the objectives we propose. As you know, the Commission and also the Council Presidency were keen to reach a partial first-reading agreement before the end of this legislature. This would have sent a clear signal to the European citizens about the importance we attach to this programme and to the cultural diversity and richness that makes Europe unique and defines our identities. It would also have helped us to put everything in place to be able to start implementing the new programme in time before it starts in 2021. The Commission therefore regrets that this programme is among the few where negotiations will not have started before the elections. We are very much looking forward to the future negotiations and our continued excellent cooperation. I am confident that we can find a swift agreement on the issues where our institutions hold slightly diverging views, as we all agree on the importance and the general thrust of the programme. The European Parliament and the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) in particular have always been an ally for the Commission when it came to working together for the benefit of our cultural and creative professions and professionals in Europe.

name: John HOWARTH
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, I’m pleased to say that the Committee on Budgets recognised the Creative Europe programme as an important investment budget, acknowledged the importance of the creative industries, and substantially increased the MMF envelope over the Commission’s original proposal. I hope – and I believe – that this creates room in Creative Europe to support projects in regional languages and dialects, because they are an inherent part of Europe’s cultural diversity. Catalan or Cornish, Breton, Basque or Sámi: identities that are as important to many citizens as their legal nation-state identities. Language and dialect is central to folk traditions, and suppression is always a mistake. They belong in Creative Europe. In 1982, I came to a South-East England constituency as an economic migrant from Thatcherite unemployment, but I remain proud of my Northumbrian heritage. So perhaps if you’ll indulge me in what may be my last speech in this Chamber, I will conclude with a few words of Geordie: Wen the tarkins ower, if the reivers an candymen o Brexit have hoyed us oot and the Brits are nee mair, divvint bother yersels ower much, cos wor bairns’ll put it t reets and tek us yem t’Europe afor lang. (In standard English: When the talking’s over, if the bandits and henchmen of Brexit have taken us out and the Brits are no longer there, don’t worry too much, as the next generation will put things right and bring us home to Europe before long.)

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank Silvia Coście for her fruitful cooperation in the new edition of creative Europe. Of course, the most important point of this report is to double the budget of this programme to EUR 2.8 billion. Today we say a strong 'yes' to the support of European cinema, European creators and artists. I hope that the representatives of the Member States will uphold this budgetary decision while working on the shape of the future budget for 2021-2027, as our objectives are very ambitious.  As before, the MEDIA sub-programme will support the development, distribution and promotion of European films and television programmes. In the coming years, investment in the international production and distribution of European works and innovative ways of telling stories, including works based on virtual reality, will be increased. An online catalogue of European films will be created to increase the accessibility and visibility of European works.  The CULTURE sub-programme, in turn, aims to support the promotion of the European cultural and creative sectors. It is within this sub-programme that projects, networks and collaborative platforms will be created, bringing together talented artists from all over Europe and facilitating international cooperation between creators. A new element of this component will be to support the music sector. This is a huge success for the 'Music for Europe' pilot project, which will be included in this programme.  As a former journalist, I am pleased that the novelty of the cross-sectoral section is the financing of the media and investigative journalism sector. It is worth noting that each component of the program will have a special set of quantitative and qualitative indicators. This will be used to collect relevant statistics and to measure and analyse the impact of cultural policy.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, arts and culture are the heart and soul of Europe and Creative Europe is the key mechanism that enables artists and audiences from across Europe and beyond to engage in creative exploration of what it means to live in Europe today. The programme is one of the EU’s finest projects and promotes excellent synergies across other sectors – for example STEAM, which recognises science, technology, art, engineering and maths. I am personally proud to have pushed for this acknowledgment over the course of my mandate. The new programme ensures that the sector will reach its economic potential contributing to sustainable growth, jobs and social cohesion. It will enable Europe’s culture and media sectors to access new international opportunities, markets and audiences and that’s why it’s essential, if the tragedy of Brexit is to happen, that the UK remains part of such a project. I will be spending this weekend in the city of Hull with artists and media professionals from all across Europe who absolutely defy that Brexit will separate us. We will remain European.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Creative Europe is actually a European Commission grant programme to promote and support international cooperation in the cultural and creative sectors. As far as culture is concerned, theatre houses and dance schools, for example, could receive grants to set up a project together with their counterparts from other European countries. As far as media is concerned, Flemish distributors can receive subsidies to bring foreign films to Flanders and vice versa they can also distribute films abroad.  But it cannot, of course, be the intention of the European Union to interfere in local cultural policy or national cultural policy, which is why I am pleased that Parliament has emphasised european added value projects in the text, so that cross-border projects and cooperation across national borders are supported in the first place. What I do not support is the doubling of the current budget to 3 billion, which we really cannot justify today.

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Madam President, since Mrs Silvia Costa has thoroughly detailed the subject, it remains to me - fortunately for me, of course - an overview. Especially since we are at the end of our mandate, I think it is important to look at the whole five years that we have been through - I am referring at the committee on culture and education at the moment - and I must confess now, on the balance sheet, that my feeling is that it has behaved - the Committee on Culture and Education - as a unitary being, working with the right and with the left equally.  The proof is that, finally, we are at this point, where this programme is like evidence that, finally - So I think, at least - culture, heritage are no longer seen as a Cinderella of budgets, but, on the contrary, they are growing by the day. This programme is proof and, of course, that is what we have all contributed, all the members of the Committee on Culture, and I would say - because the Madam President has gladly noted the presence of Mr Gérard Deprez in the Chamber, I do, he is one of the people I have felt alongside in difficult times, especially since, being in the Committee on Budgets, this matters , because it is impossible to work only in committees, only with our subjects, but to look at the big picture, to make friends, to clarify everyone on the right and the left, and I am referring right now to this very room, or to European politics itself. Finally, not to mention too much, I would say that this program, as a kind of crowning of our work, of all of us, contains even a kind of philosophy and I focus on a single subject that particularly impressed me - me being a film actor - the notion of cinema, cinema designed in the hall, has gained weight, has been fully understood as a fundamental social function and not... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which United in diversity – this is not without reason our great slogan of unification. And we all know that if we do not learn to deal with diversity, with cultural diversity in Europe, our societies will become more violent. That is why our programme for cultural diversity, including cultural differences, living with different cultural traditions and appreciating our cultural heritage and the future of joint cultural production is crucial for the future of the European Union. We are now seeing this with artists and young people in the UK: they want to keep this Creative Europe programme because they all know what they are getting from it. This is a programme that is only controversial among anti-Europeans, otherwise everyone knows the value and that it matters to the individual citizen. That is why it is right to double the budget. We have a new program Music Moves Europe, because music really reaches the souls of the people and not just the minds. We are doing more for European film, its diversity, including films from small European countries and, in particular, for intercultural dialogue.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, we value the significant increase that Parliament's proposal devote to this programme. This increase does not, however, forget what has been the disinvestment in support for culture and the deep precariousness of the sector's industrial relations, leaving artists in a situation of enormous dependence. A reality that is not disconnected from the austerity policies that the European Union has imposed. But this proposal animates a number of aspects that we do not follow, tying the possibility of support to such European added value and, subsequently, to the policies of the European Union and its vision for democracy or external relations. At the same time, it is sick of a mercantilist view of culture supported by competition, which we reject. The example of the European Youth Orchestra and the reference to the need to diversify revenues and sources of funding is paradigmatic of this view. Approaches that contribute to cultural normalization and colonization that are contrary to the promotion of creative freedom and independence and the democratization of culture.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, creative Europe is the only programme that supports those who want to do business in the field of culture and creativity. Very often they are micro- and medium-sized enterprises or independent creators and artists. They are the true backbone of Europe's cultural diversity, capable of innovating, undertaking and narrating the stories and traditions of local territories. The European Union must concentrate its efforts and resources on them. I am therefore particularly pleased that my proposals have been approved to include specific support for small independent audiovisual productions, as well as for young emerging music artists, who will have access to specific funding. I would like to remind you that culture is such if it is open to all: it is essential that we have included funding for adaptation in accessible formats of books and films or for people with disabilities, as I had proposed. It is a concrete action that allows everyone to enjoy the fundamental right to access to culture. In times of economic crisis, the superfluous is cut and, unfortunately, culture is considered superfluous. The 'Creative Europe' programme, thanks to our work, is a first step in the direction of enhancing Europe's immense heritage and enabling all citizens to enjoy it. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, you don't have to worry, I appreciate your cooperation, but I wanted to ask you one thing. Creative Europe supported the activities for the European Year of Cultural Heritage last year, and I remember a debate when you feared that it would only be a promotion, that it would just be a European label again, but it would not go all the way to the people of the regions.  I wanted to ask you if you personally met a successful project? Because I know a project like this. It is Art and Contemporary Me that appeals very well to the younger generation. It's just an all-out question.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Yes, I objected because there was a budget shift, so we were taking a part of the budget from creative Europe to this other program and when there's a budget shift I never think that's a good thing. If we really believed and if the committee believed in the project, it had to add money, not move it from something that already didn't have enough funding. And then I objected because I saw this project as a lot of communication rather than substance and, alas, I am a person who prefers substance and concreteness rather than appearance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, if cultural industries weigh so much in the European economy, it is because culture is so closely linked to our continent that it is almost the trademark of it. A cultural community in the highest sense of the term even recognized Robert Schuman, apostle of the disembodied single market. It is therefore regrettable that a creative Europe, which has supported works as estimated as The Life of Others or The Speech of a King, is in turn being squandered in favour of the ideological whims of fashion.  I turn to the obsession with fake news, at a time when the impending European elections seem to plunge the Commission into an unfathomable disarray. For the most questionable is the endless opening of Kosovo's programme to Tunisia, not to mention the inevitable topo of the integration of migrants.  In its mission entrusted by the treaties promoting cultural diversity, Brussels seems to have favoured only an ever more exotic diversity. The result is invariably a program in its image, without roots, without passion and without soul.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, culture unites Europe, and every citizen in the European Union naturally feels that, even without a regulation, cultural heritage is common to all, that it would not have been created without mutual cooperation. That it brings us enrichment.  The Creative Europe programme itself is in order to keep this heritage, to develop it, to contribute to its knowledge, to the creation of new cultural events and works of art. The media, culture and intersite component will be maintained and the budget is slightly increased to EUR 1.85 billion. This does not completely satisfy us, because many projects will still not be implemented. We have tried to make the program effective, to focus on new activities as well. Personally, I support the emphasis on media and film education. Better collaboration and networking of award-winning cultural venues such as the European Heritage Label would also help to increase visibility.  Culture unites us, and that is what we have seen when working in the Committee on Culture. I would like to thank my colleagues very much. I feel very enriched by this cooperation and personally I would like to thank Silvia Costa, Helza Trüpel, my colleague Diacon, as well as my colleague Adinolfi and others, my colleague Zdrojewski. It's a great enrichment for me from this collaboration.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is with satisfaction that the Creative Europe Framework Programme for 2021-2027 will continue, strengthened, to promote and safeguard Europe's linguistic and cultural diversity and to increase the competitiveness of the cultural and creative sectors. Transnational cooperation projects, support networks for the cultural and creative sectors, translations of literary works, platforms of cultural operators, funds for co-productions of films, fiction, documentaries, children's films, subtitling and dubbing, interactive video games, film festivals, as well as European Capitals of Culture and the European Heritage Label, European Prizes for Literature, Architecture, Heritage Protection , cinema and music: all this is 'creative Europe', a true European peculiarity. However, in order to prevent too many projects from continuing to be implemented due to a lack of funds, it is imperative to double the budget, in line with the interim report of the multiannual financial framework. It is also important that the programme, over the next seven years, ensures greater accessibility to cultural goods and services, specifically, for all European citizens. To my colleague and friend Costa, I applaud her for the excellent work!

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Jean Monnet is credited with the phrase: if I could start European integration again, it would not be coal and steel, but culture. And what we have heard today reminds me of the policy that Jean Monnet has made with coal and steel, with the guidelines, with the means and the subsidies. This can be transferred to culture, so to speak. I read out a sentence that has so wonderfully aroused and amused me as an economist, that is the letter (c) in Article 3a: 'the economies of scale, growth and jobs promoted by Union support, which creates a leverage effect for additional resources' . I've never read a sentence that contains so much nonsense at once. Economies of scale, that is, size degression as the expression increases. What is this supposed to be about culture? Growth, unemployment and leverage! Yes, my God, what do we expect from this programme? That is downright ridiculous! I think it's ridiculous - not because I'm against Europe, I think it's ridiculous because I'm European.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, there’s an old saying that he who pays the piper calls the tune, and it certainly seems to apply to the creative sector where the European Union is concerned. More than a billion euros has been spent on the current creative Europe programme, and in return I must note the creative sector overwhelmingly backed EU membership during the UK referendum. We certainly had our artists for Brexit who did not, but those at the commanding heights of our cultural institutions were generally in favour of staying in. Fortunately, the Great British public had other ideas and did not follow the direction of those we refer to somewhat sarcastically as the great and the good.  Now there’s no doubt that the creative sector is an area in which Europe has a competitive advantage. Were you to ask people the world over which continent has the richest cultural heritage, it is difficult to imagine Europe not coming top. We’ve had most of the greatest painters, classical composers, writers and architects the world has ever seen. It’s also true that down the ages many writers, artists and musicians have depended on wealthy patrons to further their careers. The Royal Court of the Habsburg Empire was a noted sponsor of art and music, for instance, so it’s perhaps no surprise to find the court of the Juncker empire following suit. The danger is, though, that yes, indeed he who pays the piper calls the tune.  The various strands of creative Europe naturally place a high value on funding activities that elevate the European collective identity above national identities. In this, the attention, I think, is to promote the creation of a European demos which trumps national affinities, and such a demos is certainly required to make sense of the EU’s mania for ever-closer union, but there’s little sign of its emergence. The danger is that subsidised culture becomes dull culture, lured towards safe and politically correct choices that won’t rock the boat with the sponsor.  In the case of the Habsburgs, it was the uninspiring Salieri who retained the lucrative position of court composer, and not the genius Mozart. I’m sure in the years ahead the next creative Europe programme will help some talented creatives with their careers. Whether it will prove to be value for money is doubtful and whether it will foster the miraculous birth of the long-awaited European demos, more doubtful still.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the Committee on Culture, we agree on two themes: Erasmus+ and Creative Europe. We always try, at every meeting, at every opportunity to stress the importance and importance of these two programmes, as well as their effectiveness in achieving important, well-defined objectives. Today I would like to thank Mrs Sylvia Coście, because she not only prepared today's document, but also the Chair of the Committee on Culture before, and has supported precisely these two topics, which we have often and usually very much discussed – I stress this – very well. On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to two elements. Firstly, we have started this Parliament's term of office with the doubts of other political groups and other committees regarding the importance of Erasmus+. We also started by monitoring creative Europe to check its effectiveness, as well as the satisfaction of those who participate. And I must stress that, with regard to Creative Europe, we have one serious problem: Only 20% of the projects applying for this programme are satisfied, supported. This means that 80% of well-prepared, valuable and valuable projects – in short – end up in the bin. This is the most important argument for increasing funding for this programme. And today I can call for at least a 50% efficiency in this programme.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Madam President. Creative Europe is a programme for all, and I am very happy that creative industries in the European Union are seeing growth because it greatly helps, for example, the film industry, cultural heritage, the translation of books, but it is also for those who are consumers of such a supported culture. For this reason, it is important that the budget for the multiannual financial framework for 2021-2027 is not underfunded, because the applicants' failure rate is large and this discourages many actors from participating in it. Although Creative Europe is also financed by other European Union financial instruments, I agree with the rapporteur that an increase in the budget for Creative Europe is needed. On the other hand, it is necessary to applaud the Commission's proposal, which has introduced an option where-made creative and cultural projects that have received a high rating can receive a certificate of excellence, which would make it easier for them to access funding. I wish Creative Europe to also have support in the new composition of the European Parliament after the Elections in May.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, European cultural heritage is very important, and I very much welcome the fact that it is so relevant in Mrs Costa's report and in the Creative Europe programme. We must preserve and recover this heritage. I am very pleased that Mrs Costa's report clearly supports more structured and ambitious cooperation with the Council of Europe on the european cultural routes programme. These routes, now 33, largely show the enormous wealth and diversity of European culture. But they are also testament to the close historical and cultural and artistic links that unso together with Europeans. We are an authentic cultural community that overflows national borders. The European Union is more than an economic and trade union that emerged after World War II to preserve peace. This is important, of course, but it is also true that this Europe is a community with deep common cultural and historical roots, and this is evidenced by our cultural heritage. That's why we have to preserve it, take care of it. It is a great testament to this European-based unity.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, culture, cultural heritage and cultural diversity are the riches of the single market. Sure, we have a national identity, but we have a European cultural heritage that we have to take into account.  I am very glad that the Creative Europe programme exists, because this programme actually contributes to competitiveness, social cohesion, local and regional development. I am surprised that some do not understand this link between 'Creative Europe' and economic growth and development. It stimulates the creation of innovative projects, this project, and knowledge of successful projects, mutual knowledge. Culture, in fact, ensures economic and social sustainability and should be a central element of political development strategies.  We need to promote cultural education, because cultural education, after all, is an important pillar of democracy. I am very glad that there is a consistent budget, I hope that this budget is not low and, of course, I hope that there is a system of quantitative and qualitative performance indicators because, yes, we also need quality in this area.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this good discussion, which clearly shows how important culture and creativity are for our societies, for our personal lives, for our relations with each other and, not least, for the European project and its values. Thank you also for your support in making the new programme even more ambitious and innovative. We intend to consolidate and build on the current success and we plan to experiment with novel ideas, responding in an innovative way to the emerging needs of the cultural and creative sectors. Let me stress once again that the Commission is ready to engage in interinstitutional negotiations as quickly as possible to ensure a smooth transition to the new programme in 2020.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to respond immediately to what the Commissioner said at the beginning, saying that I appreciate her contribution to our report and the great cooperation we have had. We believe that, precisely because this new programme is so ambitious – and we share this ambition – and proposes so many new lines of funding, expenditure and action, it is absolutely necessary to accompany the negotiations with knowledge and the ability to assess the resources available. That is why we believe that it was important to have a first reading, to approve it today in Parliament, to close a text which will be the basis for the forthcoming negotiations. However, without understanding what resources will be available, the negotiations would risk being somewhat in the dark and would also reduce the possibility of developing all the actions envisaged. Since this is an underfunded programme, with a project success rate of 15% in culture and an average of 40%, we risk fuelling expectations without having the resources. We therefore believe that the next Council and the next Parliament must absolutely ensure this coherence. As far as resources are concerned, I give very brief answers. I am not going to say all my colleagues, but I thank them very much for having spoken, also in a very kind way towards me, but I think we have done a wonderful job together. First of all: resources. Some people say that there are too many of them, someone who is too few: it is interesting. There are certainly too few of them, but I would like to say that we have done something, because there is now a stronger and more certain synergy with other programmes: I am talking about the Structural Funds, I am talking about the policy of international cooperation, also with the seal of excellence, and then we finally have greater capacity also on the investment front, with the European guarantee provided for by InvestEU. The other notation is that we wanted to hold together – we know that this is a great challenge – freedom and cultural diversity, not by replacing them, but by promoting them and also by supporting a European cultural area, of confrontation, dialogue and partnerships. We also wanted to strengthen , and above all – and I say this with reference to my fellow Member's statement that he is no longer there and who perhaps has not read the text – a third objective, alongside cooperation and competitiveness, which does not refer to a commercial approach, but rather to the intrinsic value of artists' culture, art and society. So, I reject this kind of comment. We therefore hold together the cultural and artistic part, the design of a shared cultural area and also, of course, the cultural, artistic and audiovisual industry, which must also be strengthened through the copyright directive, which we mentioned earlier. I will conclude by saying that we really do have this great responsibility, which has been recognised by many colleagues, in particular that of having made this programme an instrument, which today has greater centrality, but is not a solitary instrument, but is part of a cultural strategy – the development of which in recent years has been attributed to the CULT Committee – which today sees greater centrality of culture and the cultural dimension in all European policies. This is the great novelty with which, I hope, the new Parliament, the new Council and the new Commission will be confronted and on which, I hope, no backward steps will be taken.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 28, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The creative and cultural sectors account for 7.5% of the EU workforce, which is more than 12 million full-time jobs. These sectors generate an added value of around €509 billion and are the largest employers in the Union after the construction and food and beverage sectors.  Creative Europe is the Union's only direct programme for the cultural, creative and audiovisual sectors and builds on previous programmes in addition to the practice of exchange and dialogue between Member States' cultural institutions.  The Commission decided to increase the Programme budget by 17% and the new budget proposal of €1.85 billion, under the MFF 2021-2027, was divided into three strands: media, culture and cross-sectoral activity. €1.081 billion will be allocated to the media and audiovisual projects will be financed and competitiveness will be encouraged in the audiovisual sector in Europe. A sub-programme of culture will be allocated €609 million to promote Europe's cultural and creative sectors, while €160 million will be earmarked for a sub-programme of cross-sectoral activity for SMEs working in the cultural and creative sectors.  It should be stressed that cultural and audiovisual operators face many challenges and obstacles, including the advancement of digital technology, market fragmentation and difficulties in accessing finance. The EU has big ambitions for culture and a strong Creative Europe programme will allow them to turn into reality.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda raises the debate on the Milan Zver report, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposed regulation of Parliament and council establishing "Erasmus": the Union's programme for education, training, youth and sport (COM(2018)0367 - C8-0233/2018 - 2018/0191 (COD) (A8-0111/2019)).

name: Milan ZVER
text: Rapporteur. – Honourable Chair, dear fellow Members, Honourable Commissioner Thyssen. Erasmus+ is a symbol of European integration, a symbol of Europe that cares for young people, a Europe that cares about citizens and is a true European success story.  Since 1987, more than 9 million students, students, apprentices, teachers, youth workers, adults and athletes have participated in the programme. The programme is breaking records year after year, several projects are funded each year, participation is increasing.  It seems that around 4 million Europeans will take part in various forms of erasmus participation during this period. For the period 2021-2027, as many as 12 million participants are predicted. These figures sound nice, but we know that between 2014 and 2020, Erasmus will only be able to support 3.7% of young people in Europe.  So there is a huge demand in Erasmus, and there is always too little money. Mobility, both, and for many other projects. If students were to receive higher scholarships, many more would apply for exchanges. If more resources were available, we would not have to reject so many good, quality youth projects.  That is why, for the period 2021-2027, that is to say, for the next financial budget, the perspective, I have proposed a threefold increase in funding, from €15 billion to €45 billion.  If we want to triple the number of participants, if we want to add three major new initiatives and if we want to make the programme more accessible, then doubling the funds proposed by the European Commission will not be enough.  In preparing the report on the new Erasmus, I wanted, above all, to strengthen and improve traditional activities or sub-programmes, including mobility and various projects. At the same time, I wanted to secure three major new initiatives, the Find out the European Union initiative, the Network of European Universities and the Centres of Professional Excellence, which will be part of the post-2021 programme.  Compared to the Commission's proposal, we have proposed a significant increase in funding for vocational education, schools, sport and adults in Parliament. Let me also list some of the innovations that we have supported and upgraded in Parliament.  The new Erasmus will provide more opportunities for smaller projects and smaller organisations that have so far had difficulties accessing the programme. The new Erasmus will provide more opportunities for learning foreign languages, mobility of schoolchildren and teachers in schools, mobility of pre-school educators and more opportunities for mobility and adult projects. Mobility will also be a novelty for sports coaches and for individual athletes.  As the report shows, one of my main priorities was to make the programme more easy for users in the next cycle and to be inclusive, accessible and fair for all groups of young and older people, regardless of economic situation and other circumstances, e.g. disability.  For those who have difficulty accessing the programme, people with fewer opportunities, we have proposed a series of specific measures. On the one hand, better information and, on the other hand, financial support, if necessary.  In the report, we have put more emphasis on the importance of European added value, which does not mean, of course, that all activities must be transnational.  We have also called for a greater role for Parliament so that not only the European Commission will set and decide on the annual priorities.  In addition to financial mobility, the new Erasmus will also enable virtual and mixed cooperation, which we naturally support. At the same time, we want transparency to keep separate records for physical, i.e. real mobility, and virtual mobility activities. We do not want the numbers to be inflated by how many people in Europe are mobile, when many would in fact be sitting at home at home at home. Finally, let me express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation. Our negotiations have not been easy, but the end result is so much better.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am pleased to join you today for this debate on the future Erasmus programme. I think we all agree that Erasmus is the European Union’s most iconic programme and one of its biggest success stories. Erasmus is a true expression of what the European Union stands for and what it can do for our people. It has changed the lives of millions of Europeans and changed them for the better.  With this in mind, the Commission has tabled an ambitious proposal for a new Erasmus programme. We propose to double the budget and build on the success of the current programme. At the same time, we propose to add some promising new elements. Let me first of all thank the rapporteur, Mr Zver, and his shadow rapporteurs, as well as all the Members of the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) and, of course, of the other committees that give an opinion, and all those who have contributed to this report. The Commission is fully aware that the programme and its participants from universities, FET colleges, apprentices and high schools, are just as dear to you as they are to us. I would therefore like to take this occasion to wholeheartedly thank you for your enthusiasm and for your support for the Commission’s proposal.  The Commission is also happy to see that our two institutions have largely converging positions on most features of the future programmes. We share the Parliament’s objectives to make the programme even more inclusive, to make it simpler for our beneficiaries and to further exploit the potential for synergies with other sources of EU funding. Fundamentally, we want Erasmus to reach more people and especially people from diverse socio—economic backgrounds. We want Erasmus to become more open to smaller organisations, notably by cutting the paperwork. We also want to boost mobility for school pupils, learners in vocational education and training, and for youth exchanges. This will strongly diversify the profile of Erasmus participants. I know that this House takes a lot of interest in synergies and complementarities between EU funding programmes, and I can assure you that Erasmus will benefit from this. For example, the future European Social Fund Plus could top up individual mobility grants to support people with fewer opportunities or skill up the results of successful Erasmus projects. For this to become a reality, we need to involve all actors, including at national and regional level. What matters most is that we put funding to its best and most efficient use. The future Erasmus programme will also be instrumental in creating a genuine European education area by 2025, where learners can move freely across borders and between disciplines, and where education and training systems are inclusive, innovative and geared towards lifelong learning. I appreciate that you support the Commission in this effort. In order to help turn this vision into reality, the future Erasmus programme will support ambitious new initiatives, such as the European Universities Initiative or the Centres of Vocational Excellence. They have the potential to become new flagships of the programme, together with the new DiscoverEU initiative. The idea for DiscoverEU, namely to offer 18-year-old young people a ticket to travel Europe, has enormous potential, especially if it is reinforced with a strong learning dimension, as you rightly request.  It’s now important that we negotiate the new programme quickly so that it will soon be a reality. The Commission therefore regrets that the Parliament is not willing to start negotiations for Erasmus before the elections, while the Commission and the Presidency would have been keen to do so. We would consider it a pity if this well-known and successful programme risked delays in kicking off due to a late start of the negotiations. The Commission believes that this report provides a good basis to reach an agreement between the institutions swiftly. I am convinced that the European Parliament will again be a powerful ally in creating a strong and vibrant new Erasmus programme. Rest assured that the Commission will be an honest broker in this process.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Thyssen, I am pleased, at the end of this parliamentary term, to be able to talk about Erasmus because ten years ago I myself had the opportunity to participate in it and to spend a year studying in Galicia, Spain. It was definitely one of the best years of my life. Those who had the opportunity to do Erasmus were really able to live an extraordinary experience. Probably, in a European Union that is perceived as opaque and remote from its citizens, the Erasmus programme represents the greatest success, the best experiment in European citizenship. That is why, from the point of view of the DEVE Committee, we hope to be able to increase participation and cooperation with other non-EU countries, in order to create ever greater integration and cooperation. So we welcome more money for Erasmus!

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, I in turn would like to congratulate the Commission on its initiative. Erasmus is a programme that speaks to Europeans, it is obviously a great success. It is the one that contributes to the best investment we can make, that is to enable young people to give themselves the means to understand the world, probably to have access to a professional capacity, and it is also to train talent for the competitiveness of companies. So, Commissioner, I will make three observations, three wishes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets. First, it is to increase the appropriations. And if the discussion with the Council is having a hard time starting, it is because we do not know the Council's position. Doubling the appropriations compared to the 2014-2020 MFF is not enough and we could have appropriations below the Erasmus credits of 2020 in 2021. So we have to increase the appropriations. The second concern is to simplify procedures. And finally: democratize Erasmus. Today, for long mobility, the one that is profitable because there is an immersion, it is mainly the students who benefit. What we want is for professional learners, apprentices and professional trainees to benefit from Erasmus scholarships and have long mobility. Member States should also be suggested to use cohesion funds, the Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund to set up centres of excellence. Thank you, Commissioner, for all you have done in the service of youth mobility and employment.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, I also want to thank you for your work on this dossier, the rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have contributed. The Erasmus+ programme has achieved something difficult to calculate in money: it has helped to train, among young people in particular, a European identity that we really need. This is, I believe, the purpose of the Erasmus+ programme and that is the secret to its success so far. However, in order to continue at the same level, I still believe that the programme needs more funding. We, both in the Committee on Employment and in the Committee on Culture, have proposed a tripling, and I hope that the Council will also come and support this. I also believe that there is a need to improve communication between beneficiaries, the European Commission and national bodies. Last but not least, in the digital age there is a need for simplification, increased accessibility and reduced bureaucracy. And we must not forget that Erasmus+ must become more inclusive, it must also ensure access for the disadvantaged and those with disabilities, and it must clearly ensure equality between women and men. And let us not forget, I insist, you also insist on a tripling, because we have new components, we want a tripling of the beneficiaries. If we don't have this tripling, it's going to be hard to achieve them, so we're probably going to have to get out of quality. Thank you, support Erasmus+!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I thank my colleague Zver for his long-term work on this programme. He also made clear the new changes we will find in the programme. Erasmus is Europe's best-known and most successful programme precisely because young people appreciate it for looking for it. It has the potential to reach a large number of young people, influence their future careers and also their ideas about Europe. This is important today, when people are closing down and when various disinformation campaigns are spreading.  We have promised to do our utmost to increase the budget of this programme. We are therefore putting forward a proposal to the Council to triple the budget compared to today. This proposal is ambitious, but we believe that it is necessary. I consider it important to simplify administrative processes as well as to provide greater flexibility for the specific conditions of the Member States.  Ladies and gentlemen, today, March 28th is the anniversary of the birth of Jan Amos Comenius, known as Comenius, Teacher of Nations. I am convinced that he would welcome this programme. In this context, I would like to appeal for erasmus to remember even more in the future teachers who deserve more opportunities and awards. Finally, I would like to thank Commissioner Thyssen and Commissioner Navracsics for his approach and support for a significant increase in this budget.

In this respect, the content here follows the money and not the other way round. That is why we are prepared to negotiate after the European elections, but not beforehand.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Dear Chairman, erasmus has proven to be a true added value. It has enabled millions of students to be educated in the best European higher education institutions, exchange knowledge and skills, make business contacts and get to know other countries and their customs. I support the budget increase for this programme and share the view that certain corrections in the way of funding should ensure better access to excluded groups. In my country, Croatia, students with poorer material condition with an existing scholarship often have no choice and give up Erasmus, which is a great shame for them personally, and also for this program. The objectives of the programme must be educational, cultural and business in nature, not political. Building a European identity should not be among the official objectives of Erasmus. It is quite possible that this process would happen on its own with such a programme, but it should not be encouraged by institutions because it would mean that the main motive for Erasmus is not a genuine concern for the future of young people, but something completely different.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague Milan Zver and the other shadow rapporteurs with which we have worked for months on this new Regulation.  The Erasmus programme has contributed decisively to the dissemination of a genuinely European identity, to the creation of a generation of people who have grown up reinforcing the sense of European belonging. At the same time it is an ongoing project, for the ultimate objective is to achieve a federal Europe, overcoming national selfishness, populism and particular interests. With regard to this Regulation, these are some of our concrete proposals for the parliamentary report: increasing funding to triple the current budget; increase the number of participants and increase the participation of people from disadvantaged backgrounds; promote the european university network initiative aimed at building a European education area.  Our aim is to propose transnational partnerships that will constitute the European universities of the future, promoting European values and identity and revolutionizing the quality and competitiveness of our higher education.  The programme also integrates an important international dimension, pursuing a dual objective: on the one hand, facilitating young people to travel and international mobility, promoting teaching and research; and, on the other hand, support dialogue between countries and promote cultural relations between the Union and third countries, creating projects for the development and modernization of educational mechanisms in partner countries.  For all these reasons, we consider the Erasmus+ programme to be a winning programme of the European Union; the Erasmus programme is the most successful initiative in the field of education: more than 10 million people have participated in this programme since its launch in 1987.  Thanks to this new legislative phase, in the coming years, even more European citizens will be able to enjoy the Erasmus programme, so participate, join and do not miss it.

name: Jill EVANS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am delighted to have played a role in this update of the excellent Erasmus+ programme 2021-2027. I congratulate the rapporteur and thank him for his positive and constructive approach. Many thousands of students and young people in Wales, like elsewhere, have benefited from the opportunities that Erasmus offered. Our universities in particular have had the pleasure of hosting young people from across the European Union.  The Commission said we have to have ambition to empower young people. I believe we’ve achieved that here. From the start, one of the priorities of my group, the Greens/EFA Group, was to support the tripling of the budget to meet the target of tripling the number of people taking part, because that is ambition. I believe the new programme will be simpler, more open to all individuals from all education sectors and phases, and will help tackle many of the problems we face.  And finally, if we leave the EU, the loss of Erasmus to Wales would be a huge blow. That is why I am pleased that this report allows for the continued participation of third countries. text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, our assessment is that Erasmus+ is a programme that has been embraced by europe's young people. It is therefore important to enable more young people to have the opportunity to come into contact with different education systems, different cultures, different habits, different cultures. But we want to say that we are opposed to the tooling of the Commission and this programme in order to pass neoliberal views in the field of education. Firstly, the increasing link between education and the private sector, secondly, competition between institutions in the context of excellence, thirdly, the formulation of curricula based only on the requirements of the labour market are unfortunately some of these features of the tooling. So yes to cooperation and exchange, not to exploiting the future of young people!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Erasmus is the European Union's most successful programme and, for over thirty years, it has been an opportunity for young people and non-young people to experience study and work abroad and to many organisations to network and carry out projects. The text approved in the CULT Committee further strengthens the Commission's proposal, given that both the budget and the audience of beneficiaries are increasing. I am very pleased that my proposals to involve adults more in educational pathways have been accepted. In fact, adults will thus be able to participate in individual mobility actions, just as teachers will be able to receive opportunities for vocational training and updating. An excellent piece of work has also been done with regard to inclusion: we do not want participation in the Erasmus programme to remain an elitist experience reserved only for a privileged few. This is a unique opportunity for growth that must be made accessible to everyone, including those with fewer opportunities. That is why, thanks also to my proposals, the programme provides for specific financial support measures, in synergy with other European programmes, in order to give everyone the same opportunity: no one should fall behind.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, strengthening the sense of belonging to Europe among citizens is the purported objective that the Commission is attaching to the Erasmus programme, which has become Erasmus or which wants to become Erasmus again, it is no longer clear. This would be all the more urgent, of course, in the wake of Brexit. These are just wishful thinking.  Of course, Erasmus mobility, through the discovery of other spaces, cultures and languages, is a wonderful opportunity to see what we have in common and what sets us apart. Unfortunately, nothing is done to deepen these discoveries during mobility. Indeed, mobility beyond Europe is increasingly encouraged. It is difficult to see, for example, how the fact that Tunisia is the number one destination outside Europe among the French reinforces European identity. Moreover, the Commission, rather than encouraging national agencies to introduce local heritage to mobility beneficiaries, prefers to offer interrail passes to those who have just turned 18, i.e. those who are going to vote for the first time. It does not seek to encourage the discovery of other cultures, which is more like a long stay than crossing the continent by train. I think everyone agrees on that. But simply, we want to influence the citizens' vote.  Finally, this report is certainly interested in language learning, but still does not make it compulsory to learn the language of the host country. Instead, it facilitates digital learning and no doubt it will be English that will be chosen.  In short, for the Commission, our identity is to be found elsewhere and only migrants, who are offered language courses, have the right to take root. We therefore have a better understanding of the need to triple the budget, 41 billion, which will have to be fetched in the pockets of the citizens.  Welcome to the Europe of the world instead of a Europe of nations.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: – Madam President, in the previous parliamentary term, when the Union budget was reduced, we were able to increase the erasmus budget by 43% from Parliament. And now I am pleased that the current budget is asked to triple, which will allow many young people to enjoy this great experience that contributes to improving their work future, while increasing their sense of belonging to the European Union. In my opinion, the Erasmus programme has done more for the union of Europe than any Treaty that has been signed. The report of which I was rapporteur in 2011 on the European dimension of sport called for the creation of a sporting Erasmus. I welcome the Commission's proposal. This chapter pursues objectives as essential as combating violence, intolerance and discrimination and promotes volunteering and social inclusion, not to mention the importance of physical activity to health. A person who plays sport, who conforms to the rules and the spirit of overcoming, will most likely be a better citizen. Finally, I am very pleased that the sports budget has increased to 2% and I hope that it will continue to do so in the coming years, which will allow these important values to continue to be promoted among European citizens. And I would like to congratulate, of course, my dear colleague Milan Zver on the excellent report.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after more than thirty years, Erasmus is confirmed as the European Union's greatest success, the most significant experience of European citizenship practised, not only for the new generations, but also for adult education, sport and youth associations. That is why we want the new Erasmus+ to grow, tripling resources and becoming more accessible, but we also want it to increasingly become the pillar of the new European education area, which should start in 2025, with the automatic and reciprocal recognition of diplomas, periods of study abroad and formal and informal competences. Parliament's proposals make Erasmus+ more accessible to disadvantaged people, including those with a migrant background, and provide for the mobility of high school students and teachers of schools and vocational training, but also of youth associations. We want partnerships between universities to be strengthened, including with cultural institutions, and joint masters courses to be offered, including through the new network of European universities and centres of excellence. We lay the foundations for a real student statute, with the student eCard, a proposal of mine that has finally been included in the program and that will start from 2021. Let me just say one final word, in conclusion, by reminding the thirteen Erasmus students in this House that, in March three years ago, they lost their lives in a terrible accident in Spain.

My generation of the 1970s very much wanted, at the age of twenty, to be able to embark on a long journey to get to know Rome, Paris or Vienna and many other famous places of our continent. If we managed to get a passport from the Communist authorities, we hitchhiked with a backpack on European highways. We absorbed those famous places that worked so much on our imagination: monuments, museums, landscapes. Today, Europe is an opening for students seeking knowledge. This is a European investment in the future of our continent. I therefore believe that 'Erasmus+' will be the focus of the Heads of State who will decide on the size of the budget for this programme. I am pleased that the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education has voted in favour of tripling funding for the Erasmus+ programme for students and trainees, which could amount to EUR 45 billion.  Under the new rules, the program is designed to support people who have fewer opportunities. Erasmus gives young Europeans the opportunity to study, train and volunteer abroad. Trade in the education sector, especially in border regions, is also a priority, and we have increased the budget for this purpose. The Erasmus+ programme can also finance amateur sport and the mobility of young athletes, coaches and sports staff.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Madam President, Erasmus+ is one of the few programmes that has proven its European added value. In this context, the triple increase in the budget will help to achieve the ambitious objectives of the programme, namely reaching out to more young people and more approved financial projects. Current budget levels show a serious imbalance between high levels of demand and real supply. In other words, a number of quality projects are rejected for lack of sufficient resources, which has its negative effect. In addition to a larger budget, the next programme must first and foremost be accessible and inclusive. Young people with modest financial opportunities and people with disabilities must have equal access to mobility opportunities. Last but not least, following the same logic, I share the view that the perimeter of the programme should be extended to vocational education and training and to student mobility.
