name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Erasmus+ will be an essential tool for improving the quality of vocational education and training throughout the Union, through experiences of mobility and knowledge of good practice. The inclusion of vocational education and training in the programme will enable it to achieve a heterogeneity of citizens and young people, promoting equal opportunities and social inclusion for all young people, including those with fewer opportunities. In line with the European Pillar of Social Rights, the new Erasmus+ programme also positively emphasises the fundamental role that education plays in the fight against poverty, promoting inclusive, fair and quality education and clearly emphasising the objective of enhancing the ability to reach even those with fewer opportunities, such as those from socially disadvantaged groups. That is why I believe that the European Social Fund, which has always been the support fund for disadvantaged people, can complement erasmus mobility programmes by sharing common objectives.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Erasmus is certainly europe's best-known and most successful programme, with thousands of young people deciding to participate every year, actively and progressively building an important piece of European identity. Fundamental is the increase in resources that we have established. But in recent years, despite so much rhetoric about the Erasmus generation, too few kids have had this chance. Among others, the many young people who do not attend university.  That is why I am particularly proud to have personally contributed to the creation of Erasmus Pro, which was born as a pilot project of us MEPs, with the aim of extending the erasmus mobility logic to young people in vocational training, creating 50 000 mobility opportunities for apprentices, lasting between six and twelve months, for the development of their transversal professional skills. Erasmus Pro allows many girls and boys, who are entering the world of work, to live a European experience, to learn a new language and to enrich their personal and professional background, having an important experience to complete their training in another country. A more inclusive Erasmus means a better Europe for all.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I was the rapporteur for the special piece of legislation that we adopted at the previous session, here in Strasbourg. The aim was to secure erasmus+ in the event of Brexit, an indefinite Brexit, that is, a long transition period. I am talking about this because, during the debate, there were also concerns about the fate of this programme in the event of a no-deal Brexit, as well as in the case of a brexit with a long transition period. I would therefore remind you that the European Parliament adopted at the previous session an appropriate decision, a legal decision, which safeguards us against these two eventualities. It is worth saying on this occasion – or to say that a similar step must, of course, be taken by the British side. Today, however, we can say that the European Parliament is better prepared for negative scenarios than the House of Commons in London.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Erasmus programme is an important instrument for developing a common sense of European belonging through education and culture and has enabled millions of young citizens to come into contact with the society, language and education system of another Member State, promoting the acquisition of skills but, above all, offering opportunities for personal growth and openness to multiculturalism and integration. I would therefore like to express my support for the new Erasmus+ programme which, in Parliament's proposal, is even more inclusive and accessible to the most disadvantaged young people. In this respect, I welcome the attention paid to new technologies, for example with the introduction of virtual mobility for learning purposes, as a complementary and integrative tool for physical mobility. I hope that the new Erasmus+ will be adequately supported in order to allow more and more young people new opportunities for growth and to stimulate their growing participation in society.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur and all my fellow Members who have worked on this dossier. Erasmus is certainly the programme that makes us all at European level, it is the real European programme. This is the great challenge that we have worked on together, on slightly different positions, but all with one objective: Erasmus brings us to education, training and sport. I too believe that the budget must be tripled, because this is the most important instrument that we will have in the coming years. We will work on this programme taking into account the objective, not so much the investment, as the latter is secondary.  That is why we believe it is appropriate to work on this programme as the 'Europe programme', the programme that will have to bring us together regardless of the conflicts that arise. This will be the programme that will help us bring together the Europe we want and the Europe that we will also seek for the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, Erasmus+ is well named because it’s a plus-plus or win-win for students and the European Union. In my home constituency, our great university, University College Cork, places students on Erasmus here in the University of Strasbourg every year, and every year over the last ten years, some of them come in to me on internships. They make a massive contribution. I have two at the minute – Nina and Alana. It’s wonderful for them, it’s wonderful for me and it’s wonderful for their education, especially learning language skills. I hope to continue doing that into the future if I’m re-elected. It’s also very important that we look at expanding Erasmus, as has been said, and especially for those from disadvantaged backgrounds. That’s a real challenge for us, and it’s something we should really put every effort into. We should also be looking at a wider range of universities: technological universities, which are now coming onstream in my home country. They should definitely be more involved. Of course, as a sportsman myself, I think there are huge opportunities to expand it into sport, which would lead to best practice and indeed promote everything that’s good about European Union and sport.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Mr President, Erasmus is a good programme. Erasmus is actually Europe and what Europe should be promoting. But I have a question for the Commissioner and for the Commission: let us extend Erasmus to an Erasmus Med in the future. The aim is to allow doctors who have already graduated and are in a specialisation phase to participate in an Erasmus programme in order to be able to do an internship at a specialised centre in another Member State in order to close the gap we now have on public health between the different Member States by transferling the best practices from other Member States to all Member States. We also need to involve the nurses, nurses who are already working, because not only surgery is important at that time, but also the care after it determines the patient's chances of success.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the Erasmus programme is already responsible for millions of friendships, love affairs and even babies, as it has provided the means for young people to spread their wings and look beyond borders to learn more about themselves and others through immersion in formal and informal education with peers from across Europe. We all know about the Erasmus opportunities for students to study in universities outside their Member States, but few politicians seem to know about the extraordinary youth programmes that transform the lives of disadvantaged youth. For example, the people with learning difficulties from Headway Arts in Blyth, Northumberland, who’ve been exchanging ideas and best practices with European partners, growing in confidence as a result and achieving dignity when their own government threw them on the scrapheap. Another example are the autistic students from Inscape School in Stockport who returned from their Erasmus project to set up social enterprises, including a café. I met these young people and all are dismayed at the inward-looking direction of the UK Government who would deny them a European future. Young people will not forgive those who enable Brexit.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Milan Zver on the report, he has done a great job. Erasmus Plus is known and participated in by millions of young Europeans, and the new programme now offers opportunities to acquire more skills and skills and language skills through the new programme. A threefold increase in the budget of the new Erasmus Plus programme is very important for us so that as many people as possible can participate in this programme, in the various mobility programmes, and it is also important to make the programme simpler, more accessible, and to support and support smaller-scale projects more effectively. I am pleased that the new programme focuses on language learning and that participants can receive online language support, including national guidelines. Support for multilingualism should not only support the learning of large European languages, but also the learning of indigenous minority languages and endangered languages by the majority, as well as the knowledge of neighbouring languages, which could provide a significant impetus for strengthening cross-border links and projects. I would encourage applications of this kind and draw attention to the importance of strengthening vocational training programmes and paying more attention to talent management.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, Erasmus is a well-known and much loved programme in all Member States. Millions of young people participated in this program.  As has been said here, there is also a need for an increase in the budget and, Commissioner, you have given us the good news that it is doubling. But you have seen, here it has been very clear from the debates, that it is not enough to double the budget. Because we should now think about how we can cover as many professional categories as possible. Doctors and nurses have been said, but I think all occupational categories should be included. Because we have one single market and we have this freedom of movement for workers. I think we need to target more remote areas, rural areas and find ways to include people with disabilities. It is not an appropriate percentage in the Erasmus programme in terms of inclusion, and I think that is where we need to think about it in the future. I hope, Commissioner, that in the new financial framework you will also fight for a bigger budget, because, yes, Erasmus must bring economic effects. And it brings economic effects if we think about professional training.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, first of all I welcome the Commissioner and I am pleased that we can still confirm here today that Erasmus+ is one of the best and most successful programmes of the European Union.  I also want to thank my colleague Zver who made an excellent report, but who told me one piece of information that is very interesting right now, which is that a million new babies were born under the Erasmus+ project. I don't think we should forget the demographic reasons why we support this project either.  Thus, nine million european union citizens, especially young people, have participated in this project so far, according to new assumptions it is about twelve million citizens who could use this program. Of course I see you want to double your funding. I think they need to be tripled and I think it's good that this discussion is being conducted before we adopt the Multiannual Financial Framework.  In any case, this project is inclusive, it encourages mobility, it encourages exchanges, and above all it is important to note e are easiness. Again, thank You Mr. Beast.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, all those involved unanimously in this debate have exalted the virtues of the Erasmus programme, one of the most precious assets for young people. And I think we've done the right thing by increasing its firepower: 43 billion euros in the budget scenario 21-27 and hopefully we could grow it more. But I hope that we would also be able to inform young people that this European Parliament has approved the European volunteer corps and that the European Union is a global giant in humanitarian aid and the cause of peace; and that the European Union is a heavyweight in development cooperation and that there is therefore a message to young people to mobilisation also in the defence of European values, not only for the enjoyment of the Erasmus programme, but for defending Europe by vote. There is a European election on 26 May. May we be able to tell young people that it is worth mobilizing with all their might, as much as the Europhobes do, to defeat Europhobia and Euroscepticism at the ballot box and defend Europe's cause at the ballot box.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, your debate confirms the success of the Erasmus programme over the last 30 years. Erasmus has become indeed an iconic brand, symbolising the added value of the European integration project for our citizens. It contributes greatly to achieving the objectives of the first principle of the European Pillar, which is about access to education, training and lifelong learning. We agree with you that the programme can be and should be more accessible and inclusive, and this is why co-funding from other funds, such as ESF+, will be possible, also by doubling the budget we intend to triple the number of people participating in a learning experience abroad. Honourable Members of Parliament, this is not a trick. By boosting traditional mobility, by adding new and more flexible mobility formats, by optimising the grant levels, and by providing targeted financial incentives, we estimate that we can reach 12 million people from different backgrounds.  Thank you for this rich discussion and for your support in achieving this goal, also in the name of my colleague, Tibor Navracsics. I’m certain that together we will make this programme bigger and even better than it is today, and that it has the budget to meet this ambition.  To answer the question from Ms Wierinck, I can tell Ms Wierinck, and I will say it in Dutch. ... dat het Erasmus-programma zeker toelaat voor artsen en verpleegkundigen als deel van hun opleiding om een deel van hun studie, maar ook hun stage in een andere lidstaat te doen bij een andere universiteit of opstellingsinstelling die deelneemt aan het Erasmus-programma.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President-in-Office.  Dear colleagues, thank you for this debate, in which many of you have pointed out that Erasmus+ is, however, building a European identity. Some opposed it.  However, I would like to point out that Erasmus+ also supports the creation of a personal identity, regional, including national, and that this is not ruled out by European identity.  In the budget, Erasmus is part of the chapter 'Investing in people'. I believe that investing in Erasmus is also investing in the future of Europe, and i therefore call again, in the end, on the European Commission and the Member States to support a three-fold increase in the budget in the trialogue.  Member States often hesitate when it comes to increase funding for European programmes, especially when it comes to so-called soft policies such as education or youth policies.  However, let me recall that last year the European Council placed the Erasmus+ programme among the four main priorities for the post-2020 period, in addition to security, defence and migration. I therefore call on the Member States not to forget this commitment.  I am aware that negotiations with the Commission and the Council will not be easy, it is by far the largest increase in funding for any programme. However, I am grateful to all the political groups that have supported this joint effort, and I therefore believe that the European Parliament negotiator will have a strong mandate.  Ideally, we should complete the trialogue by the end of 2019, or at least in the first half of 2020, thus allowing for a smooth transition from the current to the future long-term budget.  This would allow almost one million people to go abroad in 2021 and to carry out 100,000 projects unsue.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's proposal, in particular the maintenance of the structure of the programme, which has already been successfully established and has functioned well in the current programme. When programmes are working well, the amendments must focus on areas where they are really needed, as is the case in the Commission proposal. In 2017, the Commission has retained the actual structure of the programme, but has also included some key conclusions from the mid-term review and parliament's resolution of 2 February 2017. The reports on the new Erasmus+ proposal make it clear that the new programme will place particular emphasis on wider access and strengthening social inclusion. Firstly, only the Member States and the Commission are required to step up their efforts and to allow for adjustments to grants. Parliament therefore attaches more importance to inclusion measures by including a separate inclusion section in the legal text and by requiring Member States to develop an inclusion strategy based on certain possible parameters within the framework established by the Commission. It also makes it clear that the Commission and the Member States should provide financial support to less-eligible persons who are hampered by their disadvantage or by the fact that their participation costs are excessive due to their specific situation.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Erasmus programme has received high recognition and positive feedback from institutions and organisations and individual beneficiaries. This programme has proven itself and has become one of the EU's flagship programmes, co-creating a new generation of Europeans, supporting their education and personal development. Every year, thousands of students from all over Europe acquire new competences and learn about the cultures of other nations.  However, even the best program has a margin for improvement. There were many doubts about the management of the programme, the transparency of the overall structure of the financial plan, financial guarantees, recognition of qualifications, transparency and accessibility of the programme, as well as the procedure for recruiting students themselves. The high quality of the programme, its effectiveness and transparency must be a concern for all of us.  We still have a long way to go, but I am pleased that many ambiguities have been clarified during the negotiations and changes that could potentially strengthen the programme. Above all, the new programme is more ambitious. I am particularly pleased with the increased budgetary resources, the inclusion of people with fewer opportunities in the programme, administrative facilitation and simplification of the grant criteria.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. Erasmus+ is one of the EU's success programmes, and this must also be properly financed. In recent years, we have enabled four million people to learn and move without borders. We must continue to develop this, and for that we Social Democrats are calling for a tripling of the funds. However, Erasmus+ must not be an elite programme. Studying abroad must be possible regardless of the parents' wallets, exchanges of apprentices must be further promoted and developed, and access to the funds must be simple and barrier-free. In addition, the range of information on offer, particularly for apprentices, should be expanded.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Bas Eickhout and Sirp Pietikäinen, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on the Environment, On the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a framework to facilitate sustainable investment (COM(2018)0353 - C8-0207/2018 - 2018/0178(COD)) (A8-0175/2019).

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, my thanks to the Commission and to my colleagues for having worked on this file, for a while now, and for finally also having this moment of truth here in the plenary to get to a vote later on today. In principle, this file really is about putting the money where your mouth is. That’s basically what we’re doing with this file. I just want to remind all my colleagues who were always celebrating the Paris Agreement about how important it is that we – as Europe – are leading by example.  It is also very important where we put our money. Where are the investments going? How do we ensure that our investments become Paris-proof? We are talking about shifting trillions of euros of investments here, and if we do that in the right way, we can help the financial sector and our industry to move to a green economy, which is the future. This is also being debated. We are debating at the Council level our zero—emission economy, a climate-neutral economy. If we want to get there, we need the right incentives; we need the right investments. We also need the right definitions, and that is exactly what is at stake here today. First of all, the taxonomy will describe and determine what a green investment is. Parliament is making some good proposals on really defining what a green investment is in order to prevent greenwashing. That is very important, because there are many green products on the market, but quite often we do not know exactly what their environmental impact is, what their green impact is. By adopting this taxonomy, we will put transparent standards on what green financing means, and that is very important to have. Of course, there are still some amendments on the table to make very clear what, in our mind, should not be considered a green investment. I will also ask my colleagues, are you really going to accept that later on an investment in coal can still be called green? While we are discussing the phasing out of coal in every country, any investment in coal cannot be seen as a green investment. This is just simple logic, and I hope that Parliament will follow that logic. We also have some other discussions to follow, because green investment is still a niche; it’s still a small part of the investments. The big part of the investments are not claiming to be green, but are still being done. Therefore, we deliberately opened up the discussion on defining when an activity is non—green. There has been a lot of lobbying out there really talking a lot of nonsense, as if we were forbidding activities; as if we were not giving a chance for industry to green. What we are doing is to show for every investment what the environmental impact is. If you have a downgrading of your impact, of course that should be highlighted, just like you highlight when you have a very positive green impact. It is not forbidding; it is not blacklisting; it is just providing transparency to the market. Hopefully, that will have an impact on the market, so that our finances will go from brown investments to more green investments. That is exactly what we need if we want to be Paris-proof. The last point that is on the table: if we talk about sustainable finance, it should not only be green, it should also be social. We are putting some proposals for minimum safeguards, but we know that it is very difficult for many people to accept. When we are talking about sustainable finance, you cannot avoid discussing what the social implications of sustainable finance are, and that too is on the table today. I am looking forward to a good discussion and, more importantly, a very good vote later today.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, we have EUR 30 trillion in coal—risky and environmentally—risky stranded assets. EUR 30 trillion! That is millions of millions. That means that our pensions are threatened in the longer run if change is not made. It means that our economy is at risk and threat of a crises when change is going to come. And it means that our environment is under threat because we are investing in the wrong end of the economy. But then again, the good news is that EUR 30 trillion is a lot of money and as we have a clear indication what kind of investments are environmentally—friendly, sustainable and not causing significant harm in other fields, then we have plenty of money to turn the wheel and support environmentally—sustainable economies and investments. We need only EUR 180 billion every year to invest in combating climate change. So, we do have the money, but it is in the wrong place. The question is about transferring that money from economically and environmentally risky investments to more sustainable investments.  There, we need a harmonised indicator so we really can compare industries to industries within a sector and between sectors. We need to define – and this is what this legislation is all about – the environmental requirements and, in the future, as a backstop, the social requirements that we consider to be sustainable. What that means is that in the case of palm oil, for example, you can’t focus on one issue like climate change and say this is a good investment if it causes significant harm in other fields of the environment like biodiversity in Indonesia and orang-utans. We know this to be the case with palm oil. And you couldn’t build a solar panel unit in a nature conservation area and claim it is green. And no, I don’t think that you could produce solar panels or any other green niceties with child labour. So the reference to significant environmental harm or other harm and the backstop makes consistent sense of how we understand and define sustainability.  The financial sector is already much more advanced than setting green indicators and reporting mechanisms. For the majority of politicians in Member States – and let’s see what the figures are here, in the European Parliament – the issue is that now when we do not have a harmonised taxonomy they lose comparability, and the information they have does not have as big an impact as it should. But we, as politicians, shouldn’t perform worse than the markets are doing already. That brings us to some of the specific issues here in the file. First, coal. Frankly, with climate change, could you really call a coal investment a green investment? Put that question to yourselves. Second question, could you really call investments that follow only basic national legislation a green investment? My interpretation is that if you do not break the law you are not a criminal, but it does not mean that your activity would be green. So yes, there need to be some better standards that normal activity to be labelled green and sold as green investments.  It is important that we get it right this time, because investors do need transparency, predictability and long-term guidance from this regulation.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, Mr Eickhout and Ms Pietikäinen, for taking on this file last year. I would like to thank you for your strong will and ambition, ensuring that the European Parliament could form its views quickly and effectively, which has led to this vote today. As you know, this file has raised some heated discussions between the committees, but this is why I welcome even more a strong commitment from the European Parliament to adopt this text. It will improve the ability of the financial sector to take part in the fight against climate change. It will deepen the single market for green financial services, and it will protect EU consumers from greenwashed financial products.  You already know that in order to boost sustainable investment, we need a shared understanding of what sustainability entails. This is why creating an EU taxonomy is a cornerstone for our strategy. It fills an important gap because it establishes a common understanding of which economic activities can help reach climate and other environmental objectives.  We heard time and again at the conference on a global approach to sustainable finance last Thursday, at which high-level representatives from many countries outside the EU, including China, Japan, India, Morocco and Hong Kong, were present, that in order to scale up sustainable investment, we need to start by having a common taxonomy. The high-level representatives are looking to the EU for that. Once complete, this taxonomy will help us develop labels for sustainable financial products or funds. It will support disclosure and reporting by financial institutions and companies on climate and environmental activities or risks and it will support standardisation, which is also necessary and called for by many jurisdictions.  For example, if asset managers and institutional investors disclose how they have used the taxonomy in the design of their green products, this will help end investors compare products on how green they are. The taxonomy will also be one of the key elements in the upcoming EU green bond standard. Finally, since financial markets are global, the EU will promote international convergence and alignment of those crucial tools to the extent possible. In practice, the taxonomy and its applications will have many advantages for companies and investors. Companies and project promoters will be better able to raise private capital to finance their sustainable activities. European companies will have a clear standard of what qualifies as sustainable for the purposes of raising finance. Polluting sectors will be encouraged to move onto more sustainable pathways by including activities that contribute to a reduction of emissions. The taxonomy will help them attract capital to finance this transition and financial companies looking to finance sustainable projects often say that there are too few investable projects and it’s too hard to search them out. The taxonomy will clarify this and help investors identify bankable and viable green projects, and it will also protect consumers from greenwashed products by providing clarity to end investors who are interested in sustainable investment, but currently have little information about what is sold to them.  I believe that our European sustainable finance strategy can be a game changer, both for us and for other jurisdictions. By harmonising the way we classify sustainable investments, we can and will continue to be a front runner on sustainable finance globally.  We will start with climate impact and then look at sustainability more broadly with a step-by-step approach. Honourable Members, right now we are at an historic juncture. We have one decade to mitigate the worst impact of climate change on our citizens, businesses and planet as a whole. Climate-focused policies are no longer optional but necessary, and we are refocusing our policies in this way across many sectors. So let us not miss this opportunity to ensure the financial sector is fully behind this shift and fully contributes towards a climate neutral economy.

name: Ivo BELET
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, sustainable investing: indeed, many banks and financial institutions are already working on it and consumers are always looking for more environmentally friendly financial products, but often they no longer see the forest among the trees. That is why this framework that we are going to adopt here today is important. The legislation we are about to adopt creates a clear framework for which investments can be described as sustainable, as environmentally friendly, climate-friendly. And this can only be achieved if we make a clear contribution to environmental and climate objectives without at the same time causing harm.  We all know that very large investments will have to be made in the coming years in order to get into a climate-friendly environment: in the steel sector, in chemistry, in cement, you name it. Also in renewable energy, energy efficiency. With this legislation, investments in clean and sustainable technology receive clear and justified support. This is indeed an important step forward that can and will bring about a revolution in the financial world. You, Mr. Vice-President, have rightly spoken of a gamechanger. I think that's obvious. Not all ambitions, Mr Eickhout, are in this text, but sometimes it is also true that it is good not to overload the boat, because that sometimes brings misery. So a gamechanger and an important step forward. Next steps will undoubtedly follow. There's no turning back. The financial world has also finally taken the path of a climate-friendly future.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (Democrats) and European Democrats, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are increasingly talking about combating climate change, the transition to a circular economy and new, more environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive development models. We are talking, but it is not enough to talk. To move to actions, we need resources, we need investments: investments to convert our industries, to accompany workers towards new skills, to create infrastructures, such as those on mobility and digital, innovative and sustainable ones. There is a European investment gap in all these areas. EUR 180 billion per year to live up to the Paris agreements alone and to focus on renewable energy and energy efficiency, while on the social infrastructure front we are talking about the EUR 100-150 billion a year needed. Resources that cannot be met by public finances alone. With this regulation we can also guide the private financial market. Those who decide where to invest their money, whether we are talking about the individual citizen or the large investor, must have reliable and transparent information on the environmental impact and the degree of sustainability of the economic activities on which financial products are concerned. This is almost impossible today, given the lack of a classification system that is recognised and recognizable throughout Europe. Today we are going to vote on a text that has been the subject of months of passionate and – I must also say – heated debate. Ladies and gentlemen, I call on everyone to strengthen it by supporting the amendments tabled on extending the scope to all financial products, and not just to those that are already green, and on the need to decline sustainability in both dimensions: social and environmental. Let us not miss the opportunity to show that this Parliament has the courage to face new challenges, not only in words, but also in deeds.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A Commission initiative to establish common principles for assessing sustainable investment is, of course, needed. Consumers are increasingly turning to organic products – food or energy. They are increasingly interested in the impact of the production of the goods they buy on the environment, on the climate or on animal welfare. These important motivations are sometimes used by rogue producers, so harmonised methods for determining what investments are sustainable can bring tangible benefits and curb unfair practices.  However, I believe that the subject needs to be approached with some caution so that this framework for determining sustainable investments can work in practice. First of all, there is no point in determining which investments are bad for the environment. We have a lot of regulations in the European Union that limit the environmental harm of economic activity. If someone does not break these rules, there is no reason to punish him. Rather, let us reward good practices.  Morethily, there is no point in adding a social assessment at this stage. I am most in favour of social justice and the protection of workers, but for the time being it is better to limit myself to an environmental assessment, and only after experience has been gained to see whether it will be possible to assess the impact on workers' rights later on. The outcome of the ECON and ENVI votes is a feasible and sustainable solution, avoiding negative elements that would jeopardise the successful implementation of sustainable investments. I encourage you to be careful.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, today is a historic day. In a few years' time, we will look back on this vote and say that this was the day when the European Parliament laid the foundations for a sustainable future. That was the day when Europe took the lead, setting the standard that the rest of the world is pursuing today. After more than a year of negotiations, I am convinced that today there is a majority in favour of a progressive and balanced text, one that gives us a question and an answer to the question: what is sustainability? An answer that the financial world urgently needs to make sustainable products. Financial products that will soon be on sale for you, for me and for every other European. Of course we can move on in the future. I invite the Commission to further examine how we can determine when an activity is not sustainable or to examine concepts of social sustainability. But let's start with what we've achieved today and that's not a story we're pointing the finger at, but a positive story, an inclusive story in which we don't exclude anyone and every industry, invites every company to make the transition to a sustainable future. The future of our children and grandchildren.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Eickhout on his good work. I believe that in this Regulation we are playing out to make the statements and resolutions that we often vote on on climate change a reality. Yes, moving investment towards ecological transition and sustainability is critical; as Eickhout said, move the billions of euros that move every day and that move our economy forward and function.  To this end, there are three main objectives: to change these investments, to move them towards sustainable investments; define well what is and what is not sustainable investment; and put the financial sector under strict climate control. And for that there are some things that we have to do that are very important. Firstly, not only to regulate investments that are already sustainable, but to cover the whole financial sector, which I believe has been the effort that has been made with this Regulation. Second, define a list of what are not sustainable investments. And I fully agree: we cannot include issues such as coal, such as shale gas, such as intensive animal husbandry as sustainable investments. This is beyond any logic. Third, too, to have a strict definition of what sustainable investment is and not to allow a certain greenwashing or for someone to put the sustainable investment seal on something that is not.  And finally, when we talk about sustainable investments, we cannot forget the social dimension, which is fundamental. That is why I hope that, in today's vote, also with the amendments tabled, we can have an ambitious Regulation that will make the promises of combating climate change a reality in the Paris Agreement, which are often expressed verbally in this House.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs for their exceptionally good work. Ladies and gentlemen, at the moment there are far too few ways of preventing anti-social and, in particular, environmentally harmful investments, at a time when the environment is really bad. It has therefore been high time to ensure that the financial sector is made more aware of sustainability. And we must not rely solely on voluntary action.  Binding EU legislation with strict and clear standards is necessary. It is therefore urgent that the financial sector invests only in projects and businesses that do not cause any damage to the environment or to society.  Please support the inclusion of EU social and environmental indicators in the existing financial rules! This is an important step towards ensuring that the concept of sustainability does not remain a lapidary phrase in the financial sector, but is taken more seriously in the future.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, today we are discussing a report on sustainable investments and one of the objectives of that action plan is, and I quote, 'refocusing capital flows towards sustainable investments in order to achieve sustainable and inclusive growth', end quote. It is quite a mouthful to say that the rapporteurs see a shortage of capital for sustainable investment. This is strange because the European Central Bank has been raising money for years and investment interest rates are currently at record low levels. Everything has already been done to increase the incentive to borrow for investment.  So why don't these investments want to be made? If we look at the objectives of this policy, of this plan, that is not surprising. I would like to mention three: carbon footprint, target group policy, social objectives. That's not an investment program. That's the party program of the left. Where is the return on investment? There isn't. So these are tax measures, and they will be subsidies. Scarcity drives the market. A production process that uses less raw materials and less energy wins. Unless the government is going to mess around with it – it's a pity the rapporteurs don't believe that. Monetary policy has already caused a lot of damage, which is making it worse. This program is making us all worse.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The financial markets must make a contribution to achieving the climate targets. This contribution must also go beyond simply complying with existing laws. There must be incentives for investors when companies go beyond existing legislation. And, of course, we have to make sure that there is no greenwashing, so that you don't label something as sustainable that it isn't real.  But we as the EPP were also a bit cautious now to regulate too many details, because we want this market to develop. Many financial investors pay great attention to sustainability, and if we make it too complicated, it could have counterproductive effects, especially since a large number of small credit institutions will then have to deal with this legislation. That is why we have advocated a workable compromise. I am very grateful that the joint ECON and ENVI committee has achieved what we consider to be a very good result. I would be pleased if we could vote on this by a large majority in plenary. Then we have a workable path that sets the direction, but which does not stifle important, good ideas.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this political premise is useful for understanding and therefore for sharing, not only the purely regulatory passages, the subject that we are passionate about today and which we are discussing today. An overall political vision that the regulation, with its specific points, can offer to European citizens, to the business system, to that large part of public opinion that we perceive close to the idea that the compass of development must be sustainable and, therefore, also inclusive. In the background, reading what has been the work of these years. The watchword: to regenerate the places of life in use to human capital, within the renewed attention to sustainability, to counter any form of insult to the ecosystem and people's health, to affirm the idea that poverty must be combated, precisely, with choices of vision. It therefore seems to us necessary to link together the most important political choices of recent years: the vision of a fairer, fairer Europe, which combats inequalities, which is more attentive to the health of citizens and workers, which is growing respectful of the environment and social rights. In fact, the Europe of rights and equal opportunities. That is why it is important for us to start firmly planting our roots for a social taxonomy. I think that one of the most important indicators should be the exclusion from the scope of investment of activities focused on the generation of energy from fossil fuels. Therefore, there is a new awareness on the ground among citizens, in the business system and among workers. This is the time for a new social responsibility of the production and finance chain, equally ethically responsible. There is a cultural change taking place: it must be encouraged and supported.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: Mr President, the Greens and the Socialists want us to pump a lot of money into Europe to save it from climate change and they already know very well where they are going to get that money: from the taxpayer, out of your pockets. Even more government spending, even more taxes, for us that is not an option. We want to focus on renewable energy, we want to focus on nature, on the fight against pollution, but we are going to do it in a much more efficient way. The energy transition and the ecological transition will have to be financed for the most part privately, which is why we start here, in the private sector, by making it clear to investors and investors, by clearly defining what ecologically sustainable really means, so that they can consciously choose to do so. This is how we guide billions into a green economy. Because what gets a green label has to be really green. No green washing, we'll take care of that here. It is a good first step in the green direction, for a conscious and sustainable investor and investor.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Mr President, in the important transition to a sustainable economy, of course, the financial sector holds the key. Because every investment, no matter how big and small, positively and negatively affects the speed of that transition. That is why this taxonomy is so important, because it determines when financial products can be called truly sustainable. But of course we have to move on. Those ambitions really need to go up. We must not wallow in satisfaction if 5, 10 or 15% of investment is sustainable. Because if that is the case, we still have 95, 90, 85% of investments that are not sustainable. That, in my view, is mopping up with the faucet open. That is why I believe that, in addition to green taxonomy, the European Commission should also work on this brown taxonomy. The Commission, the Council and certainly the conservative part of this Parliament must realise that we can only achieve Paris, that we can only achieve the goals of a circular economy and all those other sustainable goals that we set ourselves if we are able to make the financial sector more sustainable. That is the aim, and that is why I expect the European Commission to have much more ambition in this area in the future.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, this report gives us an opportunity to define what is sustainable economic activity and what is not, and to consider the interaction between environmental goals and social protections. The attempts that we’ve heard here today by the right-wing groups in this House to limit the scope of this proposal and to limit its effect in shifting finance away from fossil fuels is shameful. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s report of last October was the starkest message yet of the impending climate catastrophe. The scientific consensus is that we have until 2030 to act to make rapid and far—reaching transitions in all areas of our economies if we are to limit global warming to 1.5° – that’s just 11 years away. Changing finance is one of the fastest and most effective ways to achieve this. The opposition that we’ve heard in this House to climate action is actually about protecting the profits of corporations and financial institutions above our future, and everyone knows it. The millions of schoolchildren who have been striking from school to march on the streets across Europe and around the world know it. They demand real action – not tokenism, not carbon taxes – real action, such as a 100% renewable energy by 2030. You call them idealistic, but actually they are the ones who are being realistic. We can’t compromise or negotiate with the laws of physics or chemistry. We can’t buy time, and there’ll be no profits for your corporate friends on a dead planet.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the climate emergency and in order to implement the Paris Agreements, it is essential to encourage the development of green finance. The needs in this area are exponential.  We have an Oxfam report that says that the major French banks have not kept their cop 21 commitments. It is time to put finance at the service of the energy transition because it is the future of our industry. However, we have to be pragmatic and that is why I do not want us to have a negative list of activities, which would in principle be excluded from the field of sustainable investment, because we can also provide investments for improvements in existing technologies. Similarly, directing these investments solely towards renewable energy at the expense of other low-carbon energy sources would be a mistake. To go back to the technological neutrality of our text would be to mortgage the future.  Let us remember that the best is often the enemy of the good. I advocate a more open vision of what a sustainable investment could be because an overly restrictive, too idealistic vision would actually lead to a strong limit on the labeling of these investments.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, if we are to be consistent in the ecological transition, this issue is absolutely essential, because the best way to move towards ecological transition is to direct investment. It is the most effective tool to ensure this ecological transition. What I see is that, too often, at the foot of the wall, here and elsewhere, some Conservatives and lobbies make big statements in favour of this ecological transition and, when concrete tools really need to be implemented, they back away from the obstacle. That is why we are disappointed with the result of the work of the Committee on the Environment and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Therefore, we ask you to mobilize to correct the situation and so that, through the vote of this plenary, we can re-establish the idea of categories of activities that have a significant negative impact on the environment and restore the idea that solid fossil fuel aid is not possible. There will be no ecological transition without a social dimension! Otherwise, the street will turn against its common good. That cannot be the message of this assembly.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, there will be no sustainable finance without commitment to social justice and without democratic control of investment. The expert group report advised a comprehensive approach to sustainable finance that referred to the need for environmental, social and governance criteria. The fight against exclusion and the improvement of democratic quality in all areas are a demand in the battle of the century: to make our planet sustainable. In Spain 70% of the population is affected by climate change and the advancement of desertification is the biggest challenge we face. The word describing the situation across the planet is emergency. We have only a few years to reverse this suicidal tendency. That's why finances must stop being a stimulus for the destruction of the planet. If ambition is lacking, we will only have words to offer. And our young people, society, demand facts from us.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are discussing today an important report on the establishment of a framework to facilitate the financing of sustainable economic investment in the European Union. The European Commission has prepared criteria to determine whether an investment contributes to the transformation of the European economy towards environmental and climate objectives. Our task is to fight climate change ambitiously, which is why I support the European Commission's proposal.  At the same time, however, I believe that the approach to sustainable financing must be realistic and based on technological neutrality. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions should go hand in hand with preserving the competitiveness of European industry. We should consider the widest possible range of technologies that support the fight against climate warming.  Unfortunately, the proposal put forward by the rapporteurs threatens to eliminate a whole range of investments aimed at reducing CO2 emissions. The arbitrary exclusion of certain technologies will lead to a situation where sustainable financing concerns a very narrow group of investments and does not have economies of scale. We cannot support solutions that, a priori and administratively, exclude entire industrial sectors from access to sustainable finance.  I believe that our task is to create incentives and mobilise industry for low-carbon activities, not to penalise it. Stigmatising and punishing entire sectors is not needed. The criteria for selecting sustainable investments must be objective, proportionate and based on scientific research, including market research. I therefore call on all my colleagues to adopt the report as it was voted on in the econ and ENVI joint committees.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, this should be an important file, if the criteria set out in an initiative report on sustainable finance by this Parliament are met. Firstly, it needs to be broad in scope. It should apply to all financial products, not just to a small niche of green products. We need mainstreaming. If Europe cannot bring the financial sector in line with the Paris Agreement, who can?  Second, we need a broad view. Sustainability is not about being green: it should also include tax compliance, human rights, and – speaking as a Social Democrat – a social dimension, so that the financial sector serves us and not the other way around. A law that lays down green standards for green products is, in a sense, not effective and is no progress. Amendment 87 on the scope, and Amendment 91 on the social dimension, are therefore key.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report. Taxonomy should have been the first dossier to be the Sustainable Finance package. Finally, we need to know what we are talking about before we talk about further details. But we have already adopted disclosure requirements and sustainable benchmarks. So we put the horse up a bit from behind. It is more than unfortunate that we are only dealing with taxonomy as the last of these three dossiers. However, it is all the more important that the taxonomy dossier is good and that it succeeds. We found a position in committee by a narrow majority that is appropriate and reasonable. Otherwise, the transition to greater sustainability in finance will not succeed. There is, of course, an appetite on the market for clear European requirements and for products. But it cannot be our job to just label, it really must be sustainable financial products. However, it cannot lead to a complete transformation of our economic and social system. Financial instruments are not there to rebuild society, but society has to take care of the financial instruments, then the whole thing will be right. If we do this according to the motto: 'We cannot achieve our objectives anywhere, then we will do it with the financial system', that will not be successful. That is why I am in favour of a clear taxonomy, a clear focus on sustainability, no fundamental exclusion of economic sectors and voluntary action. Then it is also accepted by the market and also by the customers.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Sirpa and Bas on the excellent work done on this dossier. Harmonising sustainable investment is to bring more transparency and greater competitiveness to investment within the Union and not to be subject to twenty-eight different systems that only contribute to fragmenting the market and asymmetries in Europe. Tackling climate change is going to cost us money. Being able to get the economic cloud to move so that we can water the green areas means that we fully take over the ecological guidelines that Europe is betting on. If we are oriented towards decarbonising the economy, we can only consider sustainable economic activities that do not contribute to carbon dependency or produce non-renewable or environmentally harmful waste. We want to create a favorable environment for green investment and, therefore, information to investors has to be transparent in all businesses so that they can exercise their preferences with all the awareness and commitment that this entails and it is important that we know when they are investing in brown businesses so that they can be required to be given the proper responsibilities. Ladies and gentlemen, we must have the courage to know how to diverge when our conscience dictates so.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it is long overdue that environmental concerns take precedence over purely business—driven interests. Governments can no longer gamble with the future generation’s survival. Prosperity in the 21st century must go hand in hand with sustainability.  I therefore urge this Parliament to take an ambitious stance for a genuine alignment between investment, sustainability and social impact. We must collectively operate structural changes regarding the legal standards that our businesses must uphold. We cannot satisfy ourselves with merely cosmetic measures. We must, first and foremost, provide support to the many initiatives aimed at alternative and sustainable business models, such as cooperatives. We must support, politically and financially, initiatives aimed at linking economy with human rights, workers’ rights, social justice, equity and sustainability, because that provides the way forward to achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In that respect, I want to applaud the work of the civil society network, SDG Watch, who are scrutinising our work and will call out any backpedalling.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that this dossier is particularly important for the next few years, when we assume that the Sustainable Development Goals also have a global orientation. It is therefore very important that we focus on Objectives 2, 6 and 7, namely sustainable nutrition, sanitation, water, sewage, but also renewable energies, that we look at ensuring that small and medium-sized enterprises in particular find incentives in this sustainable investment culture, that they also invest accordingly, and that, of course, we also create new jobs in these areas, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. that we can bring the work back to Europe. For well-paid, new activities, it makes sense to support this approach. And I am pleased that this will make this possible.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is an extremely important regulation, but because it is very important, the Commission has a very difficult task. Firstly, you need to set those criteria and we need to be careful how we determine. Very much transparency and extremely well defined. What does durability mean? Clearly, sustainable investments must take into account environmental requirements, social requirements, resource protection. At the same time, they must not block - as colleagues used to say here - the development of SMEs. We need to see in what national context, how we can in some remote areas not have the same effect as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which has defined itself as a fund that wants to develop cohesion and develop poorer areas, and now we see that the funds have been concentrated in five Member States. So it is extremely important what the Commission does with these criteria. Obviously, it is necessary to follow up and - as the regulation also provides - to make a report showing the effects of this regulation, but I am concerned, because there are certain points in this regulation that lead to the blocking of investment in certain sectors.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate once again the co-rapporteurs for their work and dedication, and the shadow rapporteurs for their support in the negotiating of this file. I do hope that this Assembly will adopt this ambitious and balanced report, which will provide an excellent basis for further work among the co-legislators. I truly believe that this will be a key step towards making the financial sector work for the planet and for European citizens.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for this good debate. Maybe the only point to make is that some colleagues said ‘well, it’s good what you’re doing, but don’t go too fast’. This is a very peculiar reasoning, because we signed the Paris Agreement and we need to be climate-neutral before 2050. We need investments in achieving that, and those investments are being made today. If we do not get our taxonomy right, we do not give the right signals to the market to shift the trillions from non-sustainable investments to sustainable investments. That needs to be done today. That is what we are talking about, and that is what is so crucial about the votes we are going to have. This is not about rocking a boat; this is about our future economy. Do we want the green jobs in our economy or not? Other regions are moving; we should do the same. As the Commissioner said, the taxonomy that we are putting in place here today will be a global standard. The rest of the world is watching us, so we need to get this right and we need to get this right today. That is why I plead once more with my Conservative colleagues to really look at a couple of these amendments, where we are making it very clear that when you look at investments, you should not only look at the green niche of the investment. You should look at the broader spectrum of the investments, and they all should go towards greening of our economy. As soon as an investment delivers on its sustainability performance, it will get a positive signal, and that is what this is about. This is not about forbidding activities; this is about steering the activities towards a green economy so that we can achieve the zero-emission, climate-neutral economy, which will provide the additional amount of jobs that the Commission showed in its analysis. That is what is at stake today. That is worth rocking a boat, ladies and gentlemen!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the financial sector and investors are all on board already. They are willing to move, and they are willing to change the investment structure transparently so that it is more sustainable. Let us give them the right tools. You all know that the time span of the investment from the decision to invest on something, up to the building construction and up to the use, is tens of years. The worst thing we can do is give the wrong signal to investors – for example, ‘please let’s invest in coal and old—fashioned technologies, and label it as green’. We cannot go back to them after five to ten years, like it is with the 2030 targets on climate reduction, and say ‘look, we got it wrong, now we are changing the rules of the game once again’, and after five or ten years go back and say ‘look, actually, palm oil was a huge mistake, you shouldn’t invest in it’ – because the money and investment is already there.  This means that we have to bear our responsibility. We have to set that kind of a taxonomy that takes other aspects other than just climate on board, that gives the right incentives and guidance for investors and that is reliable from the investment perspective for the upcoming 30 years. We owe this to investors, to our pensioners, and to future generations.

text: The debate has been closed. Vote: point 8.7 of the minutes of 28.3.2019. (The meeting was suspended at 11.41 am pending a vote.)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, I would like to ask you, and to ask colleagues, to condemn in the strongest way possible the attack by air strikes yesterday in Sana’a, Yemen, against a hospital where children, aid workers and civilians died. It was a hospital supported by Save the Children. It is in total breach of humanitarian law, international law and human rights. I will ask you, Madam President, to condemn the attack and to ask the coalition partners led by Saudi Arabia to respect international law. We cannot continue to turn our back on the plight of the people of Yemen, which is undergoing the worst humanitarian crisis in the world.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Ms Corazza Bildt. The House appreciates your words and I will convey your message to the President.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We will begin the explanations of votes in one minute. Voting time on Wednesday 27 March 2019

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I express my satisfaction in having approved the regulation on the European Regional Development Fund. We have managed to pass a regulation that is environmentally fair, which allows for thematic concentration at the regional level and not at the national level. Of course, we were not so courageous as to be able to separate the national co-financing computed in the Stability Pact from the deficit calculation. This battle will certainly be reopened in the next European Parliament and in the next legislature. The greatest satisfaction is that relating to article 6, since we have finally prevented investments with public money in fossil fuels: we have avoided financing thermoelectric, methane gas and coal plants and, therefore, also indirectly financing the disposal business in landfill. I therefore thank the colleagues who listened to the citizens, who were alerted by us through a real popular petition. Finally, the European Regional Development Fund will be used for eco-sustainable development and employment.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, in the next programming period, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund must address a number of challenges, including the backwardness of the Union's outermost and poorer regions. In this regard, the social and economic crisis in recent years has, unfortunately, further deepened inequalities between regions. In this regard, I would like to emphasize two important areas. In the first place, the lack of or insufficient reference to culture in the legislative texts creates additional obstacles for the sector to apply for European funds. This, in turn, is problematic, because when we talk about poor, lagging regions in the Union, we must keep in mind that a large part of them rely mainly on European funding. Secondly, I believe that future cohesion policy must make it a priority to tackle the demographic crisis. At least 5% of the resources under the Regional Development Fund should be set aside for the regions most affected by the processes of depopulation and aging.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to use what may be my last ever intervention to thank you for the way in which you have briskly and efficiently chaired these votes over the years. It seems apt that my last intervention, like so many of the others, is about a plan to shovel around more taxpayers’ money in Europe. Almost nobody ever stands back and asks whether these cohesion and regional grants have any impact. If they did, then the major recipient regions would now be very wealthy, and we would have seen the spectacle of Greek taxpayers being asked to bail out Germany. The reason that they do not work is, first of all, because the money goes primarily to buy the loyalty of NGOs, local government associations and the like, in order to bind them into the European project. Secondly, because it creates perverse incentives – people find it easier to arrange their affairs to qualify for a pot of money, than to make things, sell things or create wealth. I’m not going to be here for much longer, so you do not need to listen to my advice for much longer, but if the EU carries on in this racket of just shuffling around taxpayers’ money, it will continue to dwindle.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, in order to improve the daily life of EU citizens we need a strong commitment in terms of cohesion policy. In Latvia we still have regions that experience a persistent lack of growth and massive emigration of young people. This is also valid for some urban areas. Unfortunately, world globalisation means that regions that are lagging stay even more behind the times. Therefore, in the EU, we need regional policies to support economic growth and employment. Like Latvia, many EU Member States would not be able to introduce modernisation results without these two EU funds that will make up 25% of the next MFF budget. I am proud that with this legislature, we managed to guarantee support for concrete sectors, such as the creation of new jobs in small and medium enterprises, digital connectivity, natural heritage, zero emission urban mobility, sustainable tourism and others. Of course I voted in favour, as I’m convinced that with this regulation we can bring Europe closer to the citizens.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: - Madam President, advancing in restricting disposable plastic products counts with my vote in favor, because the new rules approved by the European Parliament prohibit certain single-use plastic products for which there are alternatives, such as plates, cutlery, cotton swabs, straws, drink stirrers, balloon bars, food and beverage containers, such as this plastic bottle, because for these plastic bottles, selective collection of at least 90% of them must be ensured by 2029. In addition, more than 80% of theEU marine waste consists of plastic, we know it very well in Galicia.And the disposable plastic products and fishing gear covered by this directive also represent 70% of marine waste, so we must also help the fishing sector to make this selective collection.The residues that are found in many marine species can enter the food chain.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, I was happy to support this motion designed to reduce racism. I think it should in no way be outdated in our European societies. Many of our African brothers and sisters were brought to Europe under awful situations. We cannot be proud of these thefts and dehumanising acts. For true reconciliation to take place, we must acknowledge these facts, apologise and if possible make restitution, then forgiveness between nations can bring these issues to an end. It is essential that this generation be colour blind. There is no one who shouldn’t be promoted or marginalised based on their skin colour. We are all fearfully and wonderfully made in the image of our greater God.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!As a result of the Arab Spring, it is actually the government that has to defend the Copts in Egypt against the constant terrorist threat.Tunisia, which is an exemplary success for the Arab Spring, is a country where we still see problems in the international rankings of religious tolerance.But these problems are not really in our report.Christians do not deserve a separate mention.Moreover, bisexuals are actually more noticeable to the European Parliament than the Copts who live under the constant threat of terrorism, the Copts whose churches are on fire if not defended by the military.All this shows how fictitious is the provision in the introduction to the Treaty on European Union on the Religious Heritage of Europe as a force that inspires our policy.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President.I could not vote yesterday in favor of a resolution on the situation after the Arab Spring.Neither the European Union nor this Parliament, as its institution, has the right to call on other countries to liberalize abortions.Such recommendations are first and foremost a sign of hypocrisy, because the Union has no competence in this matter.Member States' approaches to this issue vary considerably.The requirement set out in this resolution does not represent the policy of the Union, as such a policy simply does not exist under the Treaties.At the same time, it is unwise and short-sighted to demand the introduction of induced abortions in Arab countries.In these, the vast majority of citizens fundamentally reject for deep-rooted cultural reasons.The European Union is thus weakening its position and freeing up space for other world players, especially China.

text: – Madam President, today we voted on our obligation to provide our citizens with water that’s fit to drink. text: - Madam President, Creative Europe is the only program of its kind in the field of culture and the creative industries at European level.
