name: Daniel BUDA
text: author. - Mr President, thank you, Commissioner, for being here today to debate an extremely important issue for the whole of the European Union. Last year, the Vienna Parliament passed a law adjusting the allowances of children of foreign workers who do not live with their parents in Austria to the cost of living in the countries in which they reside. This measure implies a substantial reduction in the allowances for children in Eastern Europe from 1 January 2019. However, the legislation adopted violates European Union regulations on the coordination of social security systems. They provide for common rules for the payment of family benefits for workers employed in another Member State. Mobile workers - and I emphasize here - mobile workers are entitled to the same child allowances as local workers, regardless of where their children live. The Treaty prohibits any form of direct or indirect discrimination against workers on the grounds of nationality. European workers must enjoy the same rights, and the European Commission cannot tolerate discriminatory actions, which affect the idea of ​​unity, solidarity at European level, actions that fully contribute to the aggravation of the feeling that in the European Union there could be first-class citizens and rank II. We emphasize that we are talking about the children of those who have legally concluded employment contracts and pay taxes to the Austrian state, children who stay away from their parents, whom they see only at Easter or Christmas, who do not have the parental kiss at night. good and who do not have that much-needed parental upbringing and education. It is cynical how some governments choose to strike at the interests of the weakest and most defenseless, namely children. In this context, Commissioner, what action will the European Commission take in this case? And how will it proceed to the timely management of this issue?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for this opportunity to clarify the Commission’s position on the legislation adopted in Austria that provides for indexation of family benefits and family tax reductions when the children concerned reside abroad. For me, the discussion is about fairness and equal treatment. You have heard me say before that there are no second-class workers in the Union and I’ve always insisted on equal pay for equal work at the same place. We ensured this key principle when we revised the rules for posted workers. Equal treatment also means equal benefits.  When mobile workers contribute to a social security and tax system in the same way as local workers do, they should receive the same benefits, regardless of where the children live abroad. There should be no second class workers, but also no second class children. Under the European Social Security Regulation, European citizens that work in another Member State and contribute just like local workers are entitled to the same social security benefits and tax advantages. The Commission considers that any adjustment mechanism for family benefits and family tax credits for children of migrant workers who are residing in another Member State are not compatible with our acquis. Such indexation mechanisms go against the principle of equal treatment set out in Regulation 883 on social security coordination. It also goes against Article 7 of that Regulation, which expressly states that cash benefits cannot be reduced or modified merely because family members reside in other Member States. It also breaches the principle of equal treatment as regards social and fiscal advantages laid down in the Free Movement Regulation – the principle of equal treatment that is also at the heart of the single market. You know that some Member States asked to introduce indexation of child benefits when we launched a revision of the European Union social security regulations. But we refused to propose such indexation, based on our strong belief that mobility needs to be based on fair rules. That has remained the Commission’s position throughout the negotiations on the proposed modernisation of social security rules on which we reached a political agreement last week – an agreement that, I can assure you, is a balanced agreement, built on the shared understanding that European rules should safeguard free movement and protect citizens’ rights by strengthening the tools to address possible fraud or abuse. An agreement that still has to be confirmed by Coreper next Friday, so tomorrow, and also of course by Parliament in the coming weeks.  As regards the legislation introduced in Austria since 1 January, you know that the Commission has already launched an infringement procedure. We sent a letter of formal notice to the Austrian Government on 25 January. This Monday we received a reply from the Austrian Government and we are now in the process of analysing this reply before we can decide on the appropriate next step.  I can assure you that we take this situation seriously, as indeed many families are directly affected by this Austrian law and have seen their benefits reduced. I have to add, however, that in order to preserve their rights, the citizens concerned should be prepared to claim their rights before the Austrian administration and, if necessary, start court proceedings. National courts are bound to apply European law and they are the only ones that can offer citizens direct redress when their rights are not respected. As in other infringement cases, I am confident that the Commission’s actions will result in the correct and effective application of European law in all Member States. That is indeed what citizens and businesses and also Member States expect from us in a single market.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I call on the Commission to be completely uncompromising on this. It is impossible to turn a blind eye to a Member State's breach of the fundamental principles of European law, the principles of free movement of persons and the principles of equal treatment. It is not just a matter of discriminating in this way by Europeans, citizens of other European Union countries who work in Austria and who therefore pay taxes in Austria and therefore have logical and moral rights to the same social benefits. But it is a very dangerous precedent which, if we let it be, we will start to break up the European Union's internal market and destroy the ideas on which European integration is based. And that is extremely dangerous. So thank you very much for perceiving this Austrian populist proposal as unacceptable, and I very much ask that the European Commission do its utmost to get Austria to make amends. It has been made clear that European Union citizens who work in Austria and pay taxes and social security contributions in Austria as Austrians have logically the same right to social benefits as Austrians. It is a principle of European integration, and we cannot assess the economic differences between Member States, break the principle of European solidarity and say that if someone has their children in a country with lower social security contributions, they should receive lower contributions when they pay the same fees in Austria as Austrians. So I think it's clear from a principle point of view, it's clear from a moral point of view, and I beg you to avoid it. We had a similar debate a year ago in relation to the United Kingdom, which was considering similar legislation. extremely endangered. And it will be a pity not only for those citizens, but for the whole of the European Union.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! The Austrian government is acting completely wrong when it cuts child benefits for EU citizens in Austria. The government is also breaking EU law: the right to equal treatment: all employees, regardless of their origin, have the same rights and the same rights to benefits when they contribute to the social and tax systems. The adjustment of child benefit to the costs in the country of residence is deeply unjust. It is bizarre that at the same time the Austrian government grants diplomats exceptional regulations, while normal Austrians who have children abroad have to accept other regulations. As Social Democrats, we stand firmly by the principle of equal treatment. Equal treatment and the prohibition of discrimination - that is Europe's strong foundation. I know the debate from Germany. Our position is clear: The problem is not freedom of movement, but abuse in individual cases. Indeed, there is gang abuse. The state has to take action here - it has become active in Germany too. In Germany, family funds, job centers in association with the immigration authorities and customs have started to monitor more closely. This is also the right way to stop the abuse. Against employment relationships that appear to exist, so that child benefits can be applied for at the family benefits office, will be actively emerged. However, benefit entitlements that EU citizens attach to their economic activities cannot be reduced or even canceled. We do not need such measures, we need a Europe that provides social security. My appeal to the Commission: Check very carefully whether the indexing of child benefit introduced by the Austrian government complies with the principle of equal treatment.

name: Marek JUREK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The measures taken by Austria against the family rights of foreign workers obviously violate generally applicable rules and it is good that we all agree on this point. But they are also an expression of a philosophy that we encounter very often, which has manifested itself, for example, in this scandalous anti-Hungarian action by President Verhofstadt. It is treating Europe as a group of states, some of which give grace to others and grant them some special rights. And yet Europe is an organism that must be aware of its interconnections. Due to the fact that Poland and other Central European countries fought for freedom during the times of Soviet domination in Central Europe, today Western European countries benefit from security and can spend much less on defense, and spend money on investments, social policy and other budgetary needs. Moreover, all the data shows that our Western European neighbors have benefited from the common market. The market is open. We have endured the very strict rigors of the association system and it is worth finally realizing that yes, the budget includes those who may be net beneficiaries, but the benefits of the open market are mutual, so let us not treat some Europeans as those who are to be ... text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Distinguished Chairman, I must say that I am very satisfied with the position expressed by the Commissioner. name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! It is indeed about indexing family allowances, as it has now been discussed in Austria and which has evidently led to a warning letter from the Commission. In essence, it is right to adhere to or consider the principle of equal treatment. But obviously the Commission is completely disregarding the principle that what is unequal must not be treated equally. And that happens and I would like to use an example to record it: If, for example, a Romanian employee for a child who is at home and lives in Romania and for whom the cost of living is significantly lower, the same amount is paid as a child in Austria live with a much higher cost of living. The widely differing level, the price level and these cost of living justify an indexation adapted to the respective country of residence. This indexation is therefore not about savings, not about reductions or withdrawals, but about adjustment to the respective cost of living. I am happy to give examples: in the last fifteen years alone, these entitlements for children living in other EU countries have risen from 1,500 to 130,000, so this number of people has increased a hundredfold. May I also give you an example from Romania-Austria: Romania: a white bread, half a kilo of 50 cents - Austria 1.83 euros; local cheese 0.47 cents compared to 1.08 euros in Austria; Beef 6.11 euros compared to around 19.96 euros. This goes so far that it can be stated that an average child benefit in Austria, paid at 135 euros, makes up a quarter of the average income in Romania. So this different situation is to be observed with full respect. And finally, a word on the subject of equal treatment. If, in 2019, Mr Tusk promised Mr Cameron an emergency brake to the effect that the Union's social benefits would have been suspended for a short time, including child benefits and many other benefits, then I wonder why if the Commission itself offered Mr Cameron that In order to prevent a Brexit, would the same obviously not have applied to Austria? That is unequal treatment. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Mr President, dear colleague, I would like to ask you one very clear thing.Are you aware that legislation adopted in Austria violates European regulations?Or do I understand that you have left the European Union?Do you understand that those children living in Romania need financial compensation due to the lack of direct parental care, or not?

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I am very happy about this so-called question - more of a statement - because then I can answer accordingly.What you obviously don't know is that our employers also contribute to and pay into a pot, the so-called family burden compensation fund.And that is the pot from which this child benefit is paid.So it is not a social security benefit like in other countries, but simply a family benefit, fed from a different pot.And you have to know that too.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased that Mr Buda has initiated this oral question, because he is not just speaking here for Romanian parents, Romanian children. I think that this is a principle, and we must defend it, be it Austria, the Czech Republic or any other country in the European Union, because if we pretend that nothing is happening, that any country can pass a law that is in contrary to the legislation of the European Union, even directly to the principles and principles, so that would really be the way to the disintegration of the European Union, and no one here wants that. Thank you very much for your answer to the Commissioner, it is clear that the Commission is aware of this problem, we also know that Austria, the Austrian MEPs, pushed for indexation when changing legislation on the coordination of social systems, it seems unavoidable and it will have to respect that common principle and common legislation. Austria is a rich country with a relatively generous social system, but I would like to respond to the fact that every worker not only has children who need some care, but can also go to Austria to see him, which increases their costs. They can live with their parents in Austria, and this is not taken into account at all in the proposal. Moreover, the point is that it pays exactly the same taxes, exactly the same levies, so if the expenditure on children were to be indexed, then the levies would probably have to be indexed, that is, taxes, and Austria did not do so. I think that Austria will have to respect, just as any other country has to respect, the rules of the European Union. And I thank the Commissioner for promoting this approach.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I’m surprised that some tried to justify the practice of child benefits indexation, which constitutes a breach of the treaties. To understand how absurd it seems to the majority of this House, it’s enough to say that more than 40 amendments on indexation were tabled to the new regulation on the coordination of social security systems and, even with the support of three shadow rapporteurs – Sven Schulze, Helga Stevens and Marian Harkin – none of them got through. Mobile workers are entitled to the same child allowances as local workers. The principle of free movement implies that paying social contributions gives the right to equal benefits, whatever the nationality of the worker. This has just been stated by the honourable Commissioner and this has been confirmed by the EU Court of Justice. But since we still need further arguments, let me give you some. The disrespect for equality in cross-border transfer of child allowances is one of the reasons that brought about Brexit. How can we afford to let the Austrian welfare system get out of the equality balance with other Member States? Moreover, child benefits is only one element of social allowances, together with unemployment, sickness benefits, family benefits – indexation means violation of reciprocity among Member States in all these aspects. I urge the Member States to approve tomorrow in the Council the deal they reached last week.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Distinguished Chairman, Madam Commissioner, Colleagues, I would first like to thank Mr. Buda for launching this initiative, as well as other colleagues. This is a fundamental principle, and that is that workers in the European Union should have equal obligations and equal rights. So this is not about a decision based on solidarity, but a decision that violates the principle of equality of EU citizens before the institutions of the Member States, violates the principles of the common market and, if you will, violates the principle of free choice of place and way of life. I welcome the Commission's very clear position in this regard. The Commissioner also announced the possibility for citizens to file lawsuits before Austrian courts, but it would be much more efficient for the Commission to engage strongly, both for citizens and for the Austrian judiciary, if the Commission had a strong involvement in this procedure. : it is not only a violation of the principle, it is also a violation of European law, the Regulation on the coordination of the social security system and, equally, the rules on posted workers. So, beyond solidarity, beyond principles, this is a violation of European law and that is why I expect a strong engagement of the Commission against the Republic of Austria for violating European law.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Mr President. I too would like to thank the Commissioner for her introductory words. For three months now, there has been a situation in the European Union where common rules on the free movement of persons have not been respected in one Member State. Since January this year, Austria has decided to divide EU citizens working on its territory into two categories. For those who are entitled to a full share of social security and for those to whom this right is limited. Although the European Union does not formally recognize second-class workers, as the Commissioner has said, one Member State is still tolerating this situation. If workers pay the same contributions to their social security system as their neighbors, but receive a relatively lower share of it, can we speak of a fair single market here? I don't think we can. I therefore welcome the fact that the Commission has initiated infringement proceedings against Austria, and I also consider it extremely important that we return to this matter regularly in the European Parliament as well. Because if the Commission is not able to take action against this situation, we risk the credibility of the European project and its founding principles. I am afraid that this case could serve as an unacceptable inspiration for other countries. Commissioner, I believe that the way in which family benefits are indexed in Austria will not set a precedent. I agree with you that our single market should be based on fair and equal treatment. However, it will be important for this approach to be reflected in the drafting of European legislation.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to speak. I just wanted to ask Mr Obermayr - since I was not going to ask for a second blue card - if he would agree that Austrian retirees living, for example, in southern Europe, in Spain, also receive pensions according to pensions that we receive in Spain and, therefore - look how good - the Austrian Government would save all the pensions of Austrian retirees. I believe that, if that principle, surely, seems completely out of place to you, in the same way, what your Government is doing with children who are entitled to allowance for their parents' work and for contributions should remain Sure. And to Mrs Thyssen, I would just like to ask why the Commission cannot directly open infringement procedures in this situation. I think it is one of the hardest things that makes you lose confidence in the European Union.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate has touched upon the essentials of the single market and EU citizenship. As regards the Austrian legislation, the Commission now needs to analyse the reply of the Austrian Government that we received this Monday, and we can only decide upon any further steps after having carefully assessed the arguments put forward, as we always do. But let me recap. First of all, for me, this is a question of fairness and equal treatment. The issue that we have in front of us is not one of social dumping, it is not a situation prone to abuse or fraud: we are indeed talking of European citizens who took up a job abroad and provide their skills in a host country where they are contributing to the social security system and to the tax system. Equal treatment and fairness demand that these workers receive the same benefits as local workers regardless of where their children are living. The fact that their children are living in a Member State with a lower cost of living than the Member State of work should not be relevant for the benefit that is paid out as a lump sum and that is not linked to the actual expense of maintaining a child. I am well aware of the peculiarities of certain national systems whereby employers finance a large part of the benefits. Let me just recall that in such systems, employers pay the same amount of contributions for their employees, regardless of the nationality or place of residence of the children in question. I’m also aware of the content of what we called a couple of years ago the UK settlement agreement, but, as you all know, this ceased to exist. It was foreseen in the agreement that if the outcome of the referendum were to leave the European Union, then this agreement would be null and void. Allow me also to ask the question: if you open the door to indexation for child benefits, then what would be the next candidate for adjustment of benefits on the basis of living costs? Allow Member States to reduce pension rights when workers retire to States where it is cheaper to live, as Ms Ayala Sender said? Some people say we have concerns about fraud and abuse and I share all those concerns, but then I have to say that indexation is not the answer. On the contrary, you are hitting those people who get up in the morning, work hard and make a real contribution to the Member State of work. In order to fight abuses and fraud, we need to strengthen the tools for national authorities to control and obtain information from their counterparts abroad, and that this why we have created the European Labour Authority. That is also why we strengthened the cooperation requirements for Member States when revising the European social security rules, strengthening cooperation between Member States while also avoiding excessive control measures based on distrust.  To conclude, mobility needs to be based on clear, fair and enforceable rules. These rules benefit Austrians, Slovaks, Germans, Belgians and all the other European citizens alike by protecting their social rights when they are on the move. I thank you for the support of the action that I have been taking in this area and on which we have been able to reach an important political agreement that will improve the situation for our citizens’ families and businesses. Together with some members who mentioned this agreement on which Coreper has to decide tomorrow, I hope together with you that this deal will be accepted by the Member States, and of course after that also by the European Parliament.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.Written Statements (Rule 162)

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - In recent years, in the plenary hall, we have been discussing the need to build a socially just Europe. Many colleagues underlined the importance of protecting workers' rights and improving working conditions. We argued about the introduction of the 'same pay for the same job in the same place' principle, which was advocated by many MEPs. That is why it is so surprising that in countries that carry slogans of protection of the rights of mobile workers on their banners, there are ideas to introduce indexation of child benefits. It is inconsistent with EU law and the values ​​proclaimed by these countries. Austria went a step further and, regardless of European regulations, introduced indexation as of January 1, 2019. Austria thus divided workers and their children into two categories. Such action is unacceptable and I would like to protest loudly against such a policy today. I am protesting on behalf of those who have taken advantage of mobility, work abroad, build GDP and pay the same taxes and contributions as their colleagues. I protest on behalf of those people who have left for work, leaving their families and children in the country, and who, thanks to the money and benefits earned, can offer them a better future. I protest on behalf of those who are close to European values ​​based on equal treatment and solidarity.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
